'''Abdul Samad''' ({{lang-ar| عبد الصمد}}) is a male Muslim given name, built on the Arabic words ''[[Abd (Arabic)|Abd]]'', ''[[al-]]'' and ''[[Samad (disambiguation)|Samad]]''. The name means "servant of the Everlasting", ''al-Samad'' being one of the [[names of God in the Qur'an]], which give rise to the [[List of Arabic theophoric names|Muslim theophoric names]].<ref name=ahmed>{{cite book| title=A Dictionary of Muslim Names| author=Salahuddin Ahmed| publisher = Hurst & Company| location=London| year=1999}}</ref><ref name=rahman>{{cite book| title=A Dictionary of Muslim Names| author= S. A. Rahman| publisher=Goodword Books| location=New Delhi| year=2001}}</ref>
Because the letter s is a [[sun and moon letters|sun letter]], the letter l of the ''al-'' is assimilated to it. Thus although the name is written with letters corresponding to ''Abd al-Samad'', the usual pronunciation corresponds to ''Abd as-Samad''. Alternative transliterations include ''Abdus Samad'' and others, all subject to variant spacing and hyphenation.
It may refer to:

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} '''Abkhaz neopaganism''', or the '''Abkhaz native religion''', is the [[Modern Paganism|contemporary re-emergence]] of the [[ethnic religion]] of the [[Abkhazians|Abkhaz people]] in [[Abkhazia]], a revitalisation which started in the 1980s.<ref name = "Schnirelmann202">Schnirelmann, p. 202.</ref> The most important holy sites of the religion are the [[Seven Shrines of Abkhazia]], each one having its own priestly clan, where rituals and prayers began to be solemnly restored from the 1990s onwards.
According to the 2003 census, 8% of the population of Abkhazia adheres to Abkhaz neopaganism.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.portal-credo.ru/site/print.php?act=fresh&id=188 | first = Александр [Alexande] | last = Крылов [Krylov] | script-title=ru:Единая Вера Абхазских "Христиан" и "Мусульман". Особенности религиозного сознания в современной Абхазии |trans-title=Of United Vera Abhazskyh "Christians" & "Muslims." Features of religious consciousness in Modern Abkhazia | publisher = Portal-credo | place = [[Russia|RU]] | date = 17 March 2004 | accessdate = 30 May 2011| language = Russian }}.</ref> On 3 August 2012 the [[Council of Priests of Abkhazia]] was formally constituted in [[Sukhumi]].<ref>{{Citation|url=http://apsnypress.info/news/6898.html |title=В Абхазии создана религиозная организация "Совет жрецов Абхазии" |trans-title=In Abkhazia creatures Religious Organization "Tip zhretsov Abkhazia" |publisher=[[Apsnypress]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125151156/http://apsnypress.info/news/6898.html |archivedate=25 November 2015 }}.</ref> The possibility of making the Abkhaz native religion one of the state religions was discussed in the following months.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.newsland.ru/news/detail/id/1014509 | title = Язычество в Абхазии не станет государственной религией |trans-title=Paganism in Abkhazia will be a state religion | place = RU | publisher = Newsland | date = 12 August 2012 | accessdate = 24 September 2012}}.</ref>
==History== The traditional Abkhaz religion was actually never completely wiped out; circles of priests, whose activity was kept secret,<ref>Krylov, 1999</ref> passed on traditional knowledge and rites in the times when Christianity and [[Islam]] became dominant in the region, and later in Soviet times of anti-religion.<ref name = "Schnirelmann202" />
Since the 1980s, and later in the 1990s after the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Abkhaz native religion was resurrected by the joint efforts of priests who began to resurface, rural people reactivating local rituals, and urban intellectuals supporting Paganism as an integral part for a reawakening of the Abkhaz [[ethnic]] and cultural identity.<ref name="Schnirelmann202"/><ref>Filatov & Shipkov, 1996</ref>
A turning point for the revival of the Abkhaz native religion came with the [[Abkhaz-Georgian conflict|Georgian–Abkhazian conflict]].<ref name = "Schnirelmann205">Schnirelmann, p. 205.</ref> With tensions growing, more and more Abkhazians began associating [[Orthodox Christianity]] with the [[Georgians]], and chose to reject it, turning to the native gods.<ref name = "Schnirelmann205" /> The eventual victory of [[Abkhazia]] in the [[War in Abkhazia (1992–1993)|1992–93 war with Georgia]] catalyzed the Neopagan revival. Many Abkhaz believe that their [[national god]] [[Seven Shrines of Abkhazia|Dydrypsh]] awarded them the victory.<ref name="Schnirelmann206">Schnirelmann, p. 206.</ref>
Since then the Abkhaz native religion has been protected by Abkhaz authorities. Government officials took part in a bull sacrifice in October 1993 celebrated to thank the Lord Dydrypsh for the victory over the Georgians, and since then they regularly take part in worship rituals.<ref name="Schnirelmann206"/><ref>Krylov, 1998a: 24–26; 1998b</ref>

{{for|the U.S. Department of State official|Alan Eyre (diplomat)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Jamaican English|date=March 2012}} Lawrence '''Alan Eyre''' (b.[[Leeds]], 1930) is a British-born Jamaican [[geographer]] and [[environmentalist]].<ref>''Personalities of the Caribbean'' Volume 7 1983 ''EYRE, Lawrence Alan, Ph.D., geographer, univ. lecturer; Snr. Lect. in Geography, UWI Born Leeds, Yorks, Eng., May 3, 1930, son of Harold Eyre and Kathleen his wife. Educated London Geographical Institute, Eng.; UCWJ.''</ref> He is also a member of the [[Christadelphian]] church.
Alan Eyre was co-founder of the Department of Geography of the [[University of the West Indies]], [[Mona, Jamaica]]. His academic work has focused on the [[political geography]] of [[shanty town]]s and the degradation of the [[tropical rain forest]].<ref>David Barker, Duncan F. M. McGregor ''Environment and development in the Caribbean: geographical perspectives'' 1995 contributor biographies p303</ref>
==Work on shanty towns== In 1972 Eyre published one of the first Caribbean studies on [[urban geography]], showing that the inner city [[tenements]] and not the shanty town was the first destination of rural [[Immigration|migrants]], then, when stable work is found and income saved, outward to the [[wiktionary:peri-urban|peri-urban]] shanty towns;<ref>Robert B. Potter, David Barker, Dennis Conway ''The contemporary Caribbean'' 2004 "Fundamentally, Eyre's work serves to show that the principal flow of migrants is not to the shanty towns (Eyre, 1972). The main flow is of rural migrants to the tenement slums of the inner city."</ref> and noting income variance in the shanty towns.<ref>Robert B. Potter, Sally Lloyd-Evans ''The city in the developing world'' 1998 A case study: Montego Bay, Jamaica "In 1972, Alan Eyre of the University of the West Indies published an excellent study of the shanty towns of Montego Bay, the second largest settlement in Jamaica, which had a population of approximately 50000 at that time. Eyre noted that strong spatial variations in income and ..."</ref> Eyre was one of the first urban geographers in [[Caribbean]]-[[Latin America]]n context to clearly document the inner-city/peri-urban shanty distinction.<ref>Pushpa Agnihotri ''Poverty amidst prosperity: survey of slums'' 1994 Page 14 Shanty Towns "Mountjoy (1978) includes all slums in his "spontaneous settlement" whether they be shanty towns of Mexico or favelas (peripheral slums) of Rio-de-Janeiro or bustees (inner-city slums) of India. Eyre (1972), however, seems to have a clearer view about shanty towns"</ref> In a later study (1984) Eyre found evidence of both marginality and self-improvement in the Jamaican shanty towns.<ref>Deryck R. Brown ''Selected issues and problems in social policy'' 1998 Page 194 "Eyre reviewed selected data from a comprehensive survey of twenty peri-urban shanty towns in Jamaica, carried out by a multidisciplinary team between 1978 and 1982. Among his findings were much evidence of both marginality and ..."</ref> Eyre's work (1984, 1986) also documented party political violence as a component of peri-urban geography,<ref>EYRE, LA (1984b): The Internal Dynamics of Shanty Towns in Jamaica. In: Caribbean Geography 1, 4, 256-270. EYRE, LA (1986): Party Political Violence and the Struggle for Residential Space in Jamaica. In: Nederlandse Geografiske Studier</ref> hurricane housing (1989) and self-help housing (1997).<ref>''Self-help housing in the Caribbean'' (1997)</ref>
==Rainforest preservation== In ''Slow death of a tropical rainforest: The Cockpit Country of Jamaica, West Indies'' (1994) Eyre proposed that the [[Cockpit Country]], Jamaica's largest remaining contiguous rainforest be zoned a [[World Heritage Site]] in the face of continuing encroachment and degradation, despite proposals for protection having originated as early as Cotterell (1979) and Aiken (1986). Eyre's study was one of the main academic starting points for a petition sponsored by the Cockpit Country Stakeholders' Group and Jamaica Environmental Advocacy Network which was submitted to Prime Minister [[Bruce Golding]] in 2006.<ref>[http://www.cockpitcountry.org/factsheet.html Cockpit Country.org factsheet]</ref>
==Academic publications== For a partial bibliography of Eyre's many papers on peri-urban geography see Robert B. Potter, Dennis Conway (eds), ''Self-Help Housing, the Poor, and the State in the Caribbean'', University of Tennessee Press, 1997, p. 101. * "Tidewater Shorelines in Broward and Palm Beach counties, Florida: an analysis of characteristics and changes interpreted from color, color-infrared and thermal aerial imagery" Remote Sensing and Interpretation Laboratory, 1971 * "Geographic Aspects of Population Dynamics in Jamaica" 1972 * "The June 12th, 1979 Flood Disaster in Jamaica: a satellite view" 1979 * "Deforestation in Jamaica", ''Journal of the Scientific Research Council of Jamaica'', Volume 6, Issue 2, Scientific Research Council of Jamaica, 1987 * "Slow Death of a Tropical Rainforest: The Cockpit Country of Jamaica, West Indies" 1994 * ''A New Geography of the Caribbean'' * ''Land and Population in the Sugar Belt of Jamaica'' * ''The Botanic Gardens of Jamaica'' * ''The Shanty Town'' * ''Quasi-Urban Melange Settlement'' * "An Investigation of Remote Sensing of Vacant and Unutilized Land in an Urbanized Coastal Area of Southeast Florida" * ''Tidewater Shorelines in Broward and Palm Beach Counties, Florida'' * ''Environment and Education'' * ''Tropical Forests as Seen From Space''
==Religious publications== Eyre's religious publications primarily concern the [[Polish Brethren]] and other antecedents of [[Christadelphian]] and [[Biblical Unitarian]] views: * ''The Protesters'' * ''Brethren in Christ'' * ''At Last, True Christianity'' * ''Jakub Paleolog'' (i.e. the Greek Unitarian [[Jacobus Palaeologus]]) 1997, A Journal from the Radical Reformation, Spring 1997, Vol. 6, No. 3<ref>L. Alan Eyre [http://www.abc-coggc.org/jrad/volume6/issue3/Jakub%20Paleolog.pdf ''Jakub Paleolog'' pdf]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

Katakwi District }} '''Proscovia Alengot Oromait''' (born 1 January 1993) is a [[Uganda]]n university student and politician. She served as the elected member of [[Parliament of Uganda|parliament]] (MP) for Usuk County, [[Katakwi District]] from 2011 to 2016. At age 19, she was the youngest member of parliament in Uganda,{{cite web | title=MP At 19: Alengot Writes History | last=Sheila Naturinda, Richard Otim | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/MP+at+19+++Alengot+writes+history/-/688334/1506628/-/mbbij7z/-/index.html | first=Fred Muzaale and Simon Peter Emwamu | date=14 September 2012 | publisher=[[Daily Monitor]] | accessdate=18 May 2014}} and on the African continent.{{cite web | accessdate=18 May 2014 | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/635260-oromait-is-youngest-mp-in-africa.html | first=Godfrey Ojore | last=Cyprian Musoke | date=15 September 2012 | publisher=[[New Vision]] | title=Oromait Is Youngest MP In Africa}} ==Background== She was born in Katakwi District on 1 January 1993. Her father, [[Michael Oromait]], served as the MP for the same parliamentary seat before his death on 21 July 2012.{{cite web | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/633217-michael-oromait-mp-katakwi-passes-on.html | title=Michael Oromait, MP Katakwi Passes On | publisher=[[New Vision]] | date=2 July 2012 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | first=Felix | last=Osujo}} ==Education== She completed her high school (S6) at St. Kalemba Senior Secondary School in [[Kayunga District]] in December 2011.{{cite web | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/635524-alengot-s-victory-excites-teachers-at-former-school.htm | title=Alengot’s Victory Excites Teachers at Former School| publisher=[[New Vision]] | date=23 September 2012 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | first=Charles | last=Jjuuko}} She was admitted to [[Uganda Christian University]] in [[Mukono]], beginning August 2012.{{cite web | accessdate=18 May 2014 | url=http://www.voanews.com/content/in-uganda-mixed-reactions-to-africas-youngest-mp/1512624.html | title=In Uganda, Mixed Reactions to Africa's Youngest MP | first=Hilary | last=Heuler | date=12 September 2012 | publisher=[[Voice of America|Voice of America News]]}} ==Work experience== After her father's death, Alengot Oromait decided to contest the [[National Resistance Movement]] primary elections to replace her father, who had served as an [[Independent candidate|Independent]]. She won the primary and in the general elections in September 2012, she won with 54.2% of the vote. She is expected to juggle her undergraduate studies with her parliamentary duties for the next three years at the minimum.{{cite web|accessdate=18 May 2014| url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/650419-mp-alengot-on-forbes-list-of-most-powerful-women.html|title=MP Alengot On Forbes List of Most Powerful Women|publisher=[[New Vision]]|date=11 December 2013| first=John|last=Masaba}} ==Personal details== Unmarried, Alengot Oromait belongs to the National Resistance Movement, the ruling political party in Uganda. She deals with such issues as the [[natural environment|environment]], [[education]], [[health policy]] and [[gender issues]]. One of her mentors is [[Jessica Alupo]], the then [[Minister of Education]] and [[Parliament of Uganda|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for the Katakwi District Women's Representative.{{cite web |url=http://www.ucu.ac.ug/thestandard/news/1858-alengot-19-year-old-mp-joins-ucu.html |title=Alengot, 19 Year Old MP Joins UCU |accessdate=18 May 2014 |first=and Esther Namusimbi |last=Dennis Wandera |date=2 October 2012 |publisher=[[Uganda Christian University|The Standard]] (Uganda Christian University) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519074125/http://www.ucu.ac.ug/thestandard/news/1858-alengot-19-year-old-mp-joins-ucu.html |archivedate=19 May 2014 }} {{cite web|url=http://www.axadletimes.com/africa/proscovia-oromait-alengot-at-19-this-girl-is-africa-s-youngest-mp.html#axzz2uMJlo6q8|title=Proscovia Oromait Alengot At 19, This Girl Is Africa’s Youngest MP|date=7 October 2012|accessdate=18 May 2014|publisher=Axadletimes.com|first=.|last=.}} ==See also== * [[Cabinet of Uganda]] * [[Yvonne Khamati]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.parliament.go.ug Website of the Parliament of Uganda] *[http://allafrica.com/stories/201207240126.html Uganda Parliament Honors Late MP Michael Oromait] {{DEFAULTSORT:Oromait, Alengot}} [[Category:1993 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Uganda]] [[Category:People from Katakwi District]] [[Category:People from Eastern Region, Uganda]] [[Category:Itesot people]] [[Category:National Resistance Movement politicians]] [[Category:People from Teso sub-region]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Women members of the Parliament of Uganda]]

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Anton C. Bacalbașa | image = Toni Bacalbaşa fotografie MI mar68.jpg | imagesize = 230px | caption = Photograph of Bacalbașa, ca. 1890 | pseudonym = {{Flatlist| *Toni Bacalbașa * Tony Bacalbașa * Inot * Jus. * Rigolo * Wunderkind * Wus. * Zig. }} | birth_date = {{birth date|1865|2|21}} | birth_place = [[Brăila]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1899|10|1|1865|2|21}} | death_place = | occupation = {{Flatlist| * humorist * opinion journalist * poet * politician }} | nationality = [[Romania]]n | period = ca. 1881–1899 | genre = {{Flatlist| * [[satire]] * [[novella]] * [[parody]] * [[sketch story]] * [[memoir]] * [[epigram]] * [[revue]] }} | subject = | movement = {{Flatlist| * ''[[Literatorul]]'' * ''[[Contemporanul]]'' }} | signature = }} '''Anton Costache Bacalbașa''' ({{IPA-ro|anˈton kosˈtake bakalˈbaʃa}}, commonly known as '''Toni''' or '''Tony Bacalbașa''', pen names '''Rigolo''', '''Wunderkind''',<ref>Călinescu, p.564; Cosco, p.114</ref> '''{{Not a typo|Inot}}''',<ref name="pdpdems2">{{ro icon}} Paul D. Popescu, [http://www.ziarulprahova.ro/stiri/cultura/106570/mic-dictionar-al-presei-prahovene-%E2%80%93-democratia-sociala-ii "Mic dicționar al presei prahovene – ''Democrația Socială'' (II)"], in ''[[Ziarul Prahova]]'', February 11, 2012</ref> '''Jus.''', '''Wus.''', '''Zig.''' etc.;<ref name="vdpierre">{{ro icon}} Victor Durnea, [http://revistacultura.ro/nou/2011/02/enigmaticul-i-saint-pierre/ "Enigmaticul I. Saint Pierre"], in ''Cultura'', Nr. 312, February 2011</ref> February 21, 1865 – October 1, 1899) was a [[Romania]]n political journalist, humorist and politician, chiefly remembered for his [[Antimilitarism|antimilitaristic]] series ''[[Moș Teacă]]''. Together with his brothers [[Ioan Bacalbașa|Ioan]] and [[Constantin Bacalbașa|Constantin]], he entered public life as a [[Republicanism|republican]] and [[Socialism|socialist]] militant. For a while, his career was intertwined with that of [[Marxism|Marxist]] doyen [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]], who inspired in him the idea of a socialist art addressed to the masses. He was himself a popularizer of Marxist ideas, and one of the first Marxist intellectuals in Romanian political history.
After 1893, Bacalbașa was at the center of Marxist politics, as an executive of the [[Romanian Social Democratic Workers' Party]] (PSDMR). While active within the socialist movement and making his essential contributions to [[Romanian humor|Romanian comediography]], Toni joined [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], his close friend, in editing the satirical magazine ''[[Moftul Român]]''. He helped [[Constantin Mille]] to turn ''[[Adevărul]]'' daily into a socialist tribune, serving as its editor and directing its short-lived literary supplement (''Adevărul Literar''). His choice of subjects and his perceived harshness were the subject of several controversies, and, in 1894, he defended the ''Adevărul'' office building from rioting anti-socialist students. Over the following years, Bacalbașa drifted away from both ''Adevărul'' and the PSDMR, switching his allegiance to the political club formed around [[Nicolae Fleva]].
At the time of his death, aged 34, Bacalbașa had served in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]] as a representative of the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]]. Despite this change in politics, he is mainly credited for his early contributions to [[Romanian literature]], most of which reflect his critique of the political mainstream in the [[Kingdom of Romania|monarchical era]]. He created the stereotype of the cruel, violent and incompetent officer, and brought to public attention the hazing of young recruits.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Bacalbașa was a native of [[Brăila]], where his father Costache was serving as [[Romanian Police|Police]] chief. The family traced its origins to [[Gorj County]], changing their name from ''Telescu'' to ''Bacalbașa'' (literally, "head of the [[grocer]]s") when one of them became leader of a [[guild]] in [[Galați]]. Costache had a military career in autonomous [[Wallachia]], from 1834 to 1841, then settled in Brăila with his wife Aneta; they had thirteen children, seven of whom died before reaching maturity. According to literary historian [[George Călinescu]], the exact date of Anton's birth is a mystery, but, judging by one of Toni's poems, may be February 21, 1865.<ref name="gc564">Călinescu, p.564</ref>
Authors note that Toni was a passionate and extrovert person, but with a generally weak constitution.<ref>Călinescu, p.564; Cosco, ''passim''; Kirițescu, p.46</ref> Born prematurely,<ref>Sanielevici, p.220</ref> he was reputedly an [[Epilepsy|epileptic]].<ref name="iisalon296">{{ro icon}} Ilie Ighel, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/familia/1894/BCUCLUJ_FP_279290_1894_030_25.pdf "Salon. Din Bucureșci"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 25/1894, p.296 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> In one of his later poems, Bacalbașa describes himself as unattractive, uncouth, "wax-faced, dead-eyed", and pessimistic.<ref name="gc564"/>
The boy had difficulties completing his education. He attended school only up to the 8th grade, and, upon turning 17, volunteered for service in the [[Romanian Land Forces]],<ref name="gc564"/> where he became a Sergeant.<ref name="if7">Felea, p.7</ref> He preserved a bittersweet record of his army service, reflected in both ''Moș Teacă'' and some [[memoir]]s of military life.<ref name="gc564"/> According to his own account, he was insulted by a senior officer for not reporting to him concerning the suicide of one recruit; he avenged himself by punching his superior in front of the entire company. Bacalbașa faced a [[court-martial]] but, since the recruits refused to report him, was merely demoted.<ref name="if7"/>
After leaving the Land Forces, he moved to the capital, [[Bucharest]], where he began associating with the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|left-liberal]], [[Radicalism (historical)|Radical]] and socialist milieus. He was, by various accounts, a good public speaker, who knew how to address the workers,<ref name="gc564"/> but who avoided issues of doctrine and made ample use of "mean gibes" against the politicians in power.<ref name="ck47">Kirițescu, p.47</ref> Bacalbașa and his brothers became interested in socialist politics at a time when the local socialist movement was taking its first steps. In 1879, Constantin established a leftist magazine, called ''Drepturile Omului'' ("Human Rights").<ref name="zocapitala">{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/capitala_de_odinioar "Capitala de odinioară"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 13/2001</ref>
The Romanian socialist clubs, which first held congress during that year, were still undecided about which school of thought should inspire their agenda: Marxism, [[Lassallism]], [[Anarchism]] and [[Nihilist movement|Nihilism]] each had adherents in Romania.<ref>''110 ani...'', p.11; Hitchins, pp.374–376</ref> The proponents of a non-violent and liberal Marxism, as theorized political refugee Dobrogeanu-Gherea, eventually won the day, and the socialist clubs began constructing programs for a [[Collectivism|collectivist]] economy.<ref>''110 ani...'', pp.11–12; Hitchins, pp.376–377</ref> Anton Bacalbașa had an essential contribution in this process. After 1881, he joined the Marxist group around ''[[Contemporanul]]'' magazine.<ref>''110 ani...'', p.11</ref> His 1883 brochure, ''Capitalul'', was the first ever introduction to, and summary of, [[Karl Marx]]'s ''[[Das Kapital]]''.<ref>Hitchins, p.376</ref> Bacalbașa's literary ambitions were satisfied the same year. Some of his poems saw print in the magazine ''[[Literatorul]]'', which was put out in Bucharest by writer [[Alexandru Macedonski]].<ref name="gc564"/>
Constantin Bacalbașa continued to take the initiative when it came to publicizing Gherea's cause. His 1883 magazine ''Emanciparea'' ("The Emancipation") made history for circulating portions of [[Jules Guesde]]'s version of the "socialist catechism".<ref>{{ro icon}} Mircea Dumitriu, [http://www.romanialibera.ro/cultura/aldine/clarificari-si-replieri-doctrinare-113037.html "Socialiștii români la început de drum. Clarificări și replieri doctrinare"], in ''[[România Liberă]]'', December 7, 2007</ref> As the years progressed, Anton himself joined in the effort: in 1887, he became the editorial director of ''Desrobirea'' (also translatable as "The Emancipation"), which advertised itself as a voice of the "working men party" (''partidul lucrătorilor'').<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/3265/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_279290_1887_023_45.pdf "Literatură și arte"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 45/1887, p.539 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
===Democratic Radical, Sotir, ''Democrația Socială''=== [[File:Socialist circle in Bucharest, 1892.jpeg|thumb|400px|An 1892 gathering at Sotir, with [[Constantin Mille]] (holding his two daughters), [[Vasile Morțun]] and [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]] seated in the foreground. Toni, in the white hat, is standing behind Morțun, holding him by the shoulder. [[Alexandru Ionescu (socialist militant)|Alexandru Ionescu]] and [[C. Z. Buzdugan]] are reclining in front of them. Also pictured, first from the left in the same row, is poet [[Artur Stavri]]. [[Simion Sanielevici]], [[Henric Streitman]], [[Henric Sanielevici]], [[Ion Păun-Pincio]] are among those standing in the bottom row]] Anton Bacalbașa ran for a seat in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]] ([[Ilfov County]], 3rd College), during the [[Romanian general election, October 1888|election of October 1888]], picking up just 6 votes.<ref>"Alegerile generale pentru Cameră. Colegiul III", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', October 16, 1888, p.1</ref> By then, Dobrogeanu-Gherea and his pupils had caught negative attention from the governing [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]], and especially from the Conservatives' political-literary faction, ''[[Junimea]]''. In 1889, by means of the socialist press, Bacalbașa popularized the rumor that a Conservative-''Junimist'' cabinet was working on expelling Gherea from the country.<ref>Ornea (1998, II), p.315</ref> Gherea himself was alarmed by this, and requested an audience with ''Junimea'' leader and [[Ministry of Education, Research, Youth and Sport (Romania)|Education Minister]] [[Titu Maiorescu]]. Maiorescu reassured Gherea that his followers had no intention of sabotaging the socialist clubs in this disputable manner.<ref>Ornea (1998, II), pp.315–316</ref>
Around that time, Toni and his brothers became members of the [[Radical Party (Romania)|Democratic Radical Party]], a short-lived and eclectic liberal faction, whose founder and leader was the ex-''Junimist'' [[George Panu]].<ref name="ibtraseism">{{ro icon}} [[Ion Bulei]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/lumea-romaneasca-la-1900-traseismul-in-politica-la-sfarsitul-secolului-al-xix-lea-cazul-gheorghe-panu-4972523/ "Lumea românească la 1900. Traseismul în politică la sfârșitul secolului al XIX-lea. Cazul Gheorghe Panu"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', October 8, 2009</ref> Constantin was afterward the publisher of Panu's political newspaper, ''[[Lupta]]''.<ref name="zocapitala"/> Panu and his men tried to negotiate an alliance against the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL), which had for long been the nominal leftist side of Romania's [[two-party system]]. Their program included a promise that the outgoing PNL [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]], [[Ion Brătianu]], would be made to face trial. The PNL's [[George D. Pallade]] reported with sarcasm that Panu's promise to fight corruption "with the Bacalbașas" could only bring his party votes from "the naive".<ref name="ibtraseism"/>
Both Toni and Constantin were press delegates to the 1890 Congress of Students in [[Botoșani]], a major affair which involved both Conservatives and socialists.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/romanul/1912/BCUCLUJ_FP_P2581_1912_002_0079.pdf "Amintiri despre artistul Liciu"], in ''Românul (Arad)'', Nr. 79/1912, p.10 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> In June 1891, "Bacalbașa Anton" was also announced as one of the leading contributors to the literary magazine ''Ecoul Sĕptĕmânii'' ("The Weekly Echo"), alongside a gathering of journalists and social activists: [[Traian Demetrescu]], [[Saniel Grossman]], [[Gheorghe Kernbach|Gheorghe "din Moldova" Kernbach]], [[Dumitru Constantinescu-Teleormăneanu|Dumitru Teleor]], [[Maica Smara]], Berman Goldner-Giordano etc.<ref name="salonl&a262">{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/familia/1891/BCUCLUJ_FP_279290_1891_027_22.pdf "Salon. Literatură și arte"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 22/1891, p.262 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Also joining them were draftsmen [[Nicolae Vermont]] and [[Constantin Jiquidi]].<ref name="salonl&a262"/>
Toni was later inducted into the Marxist club formed by Constantin Mille at Sotir Hall, Bucharest, and lectured for the public on a weekly basis.<ref>Cosco, p.114; Felea, p.7</ref> Author [[Constantin Kirițescu]], who joined the Sotir group as a 17-year-old, recalls that both men "carried the brunt" of organizing and educating the socialist sympathizers.<ref name="ck47"/> According to journalist I. Felea, Toni, who "resembled [[Ferdinand Lassalle]] in looks and speech", was a favorite of the Bucharest workers, and made an impression on them by touching the issue of penniless senior citizens.<ref>Felea, p.7. See also Sanielevici, pp.219–220</ref> Bacalbașa himself did not have a stable domicile, and slept on the tables at Sotir.<ref name="if7"/> By 1893, Kirițescu notes, the task of representing "Marxist orthodoxy" had fallen on a new arrival, [[Ioan Nădejde]]; the "occult leader" Dobrogeanu-Gherea, already "an invalid", was rarely visiting the club, and was losing support among the rank and file.<ref>Kirițescu, pp.48–49</ref> Two other figures, [[Alexandru Ionescu (socialist militant)|Alexandru Ionescu]] and Alexandru Georgescu, represented the working class on the Sotir presidium, but they were both in the process of becoming prosperous businessmen.<ref>Kirițescu, p.48</ref>
Beginning in early 1892, Toni centered his activity on the industrial hub of [[Ploiești]], where he became managing editor of ''Democrația Socială'' ("[[Social Democracy]]"). The weekly paper was financed by a lawyer and entrepreneur, [[Alexandru Radovici]], and was originally apolitical, but moved to the left once Bacalbașa took over.<ref name="pdpdems1">{{ro icon}} Paul D. Popescu, [http://www.ziarulprahova.ro/stiri/cultura/106156/mic-dictionar-al-presei-prahovene-%E2%80%93-democratia-sociala-i "Mic dicționar al presei prahovene – ''Democrația Socială'' (I)"], in ''[[Ziarul Prahova]]'', February 4, 2012</ref> He himself lived for a while in the city, and, like Radovici, sat on the Ploiești Workers' Club Executive Committee.<ref name="pdpdems1"/> ''Democrația Socială'' became a rather important voice for the socialist movement, receiving collaborations from Gherea, Demetrescu, Mille, I. Nădejde, [[Sofia Nădejde]], [[O. Carp]] and [[George Diamandy]].<ref name="pdpdems1"/> According to historian Paul D. Popescu, the editorial opinion was divisible into three factions: Gherea was the [[Reformism|evolutionary socialist]], Radovici the [[Liberal democracy|liberal democrat]]; Toni, who made a lasting impression among the readers, represented the [[far left]], prophesying the [[dictatorship of the proletariat]].<ref name="pdpdems1"/>
Around that date, Anton Bacalbașa endorsed [[didactic art]], as envisaged by Gherea. The socialists were unnerved by Conservative theorists, who countered with the principle of [[art for art's sake]]. Initially, this was a direct dispute with ''Junimea'' and Maiorescu. Cultural historian [[Z. Ornea]] thus notes that, while Dobrogeanu-Gherea kept silent, his young pupils launched "a veritable anti-''Junimist'' campaign"; among those he lists in this category are Bacalbașa, Demetrescu, S. Nădejde and [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]], along with [[Dimitrie Anghel]], [[Emil Fagure]], [[Raicu Ionescu-Rion]], [[Henric Sanielevici]], [[Constantin Stere]] and [[Avram Steuerman-Rodion]].<ref>Ornea (1998, II), pp.357–358</ref> At ''Democrația Socială'', Toni wrote in favor of a workers' art, inspired by the sheer realities of industrial life, and published, in addition to his own short prose, fragments from various socially minded authors—[[Mór Jókai]], [[Guy de Maupassant]], [[Mircea Rosetti]], [[Ivan Turgenev]], [[Émile Zola]] etc.<ref name="pdpdems2"/>
===''Moftul Român''=== [[File:Constantin Jiquidi - Un poet simbolist.JPG|thumb|260px|"The [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Symbolist poet]]", as portrayed by ''[[Moftul Român]]'' cartoonist [[Constantin Jiquidi]]]] The busiest part of Toni Bacalbașa's short career covers the years 1893–1894. He had by then befriended the influential satirist Caragiale, and, with him, began work on the humorous gazette ''[[Moftul Român]]''. The two authors had different backgrounds: to Bacalbașa's socialism, Caragiale opposed a conservatism formed during his stay with ''Junimea''. Literary historian [[Tudor Vianu]] notes that, in a cheerful manner, ''Moftul'' reflected that ''Junimist'' agenda, skeptical toward all cultural innovation.<ref>Vianu, pp.183–184</ref> According to philologist [[Ștefan Cazimir]], the magazine was mainly a [[parody]] of the [[Neoromanticism|neoromantic]] and modern [[kitsch]], prevalent in the ''[[fin de siècle]]''.<ref>Cazimir, pp.20–21, 28–31</ref> Its title translates into "The Romanian Trifle" or "The Romanian Nonsense", referencing one's uppity answer to things presented as new: ''moft!'' (in the same sense of "bollocks!"). ''Moftul'' editorials had it that ''moft!'' was a national characteristic, what "spleen" is to the [[English people|English]], "chauvinism" to the [[Hungarians]], and "Nihilism" to the [[Russians]].<ref>Vianu, p.183</ref>
Caragiale's paper was in large part poking fun at the nationalist and traditionalist current in [[Romanian literature]], parodying stories about peasant life.<ref>Cioculescu, pp.41–46; Vianu, p.185</ref> A predilect victim was the nationalist scholar and Caragiale critic [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]], his life's work of gathering etymological data ridiculed as "the ''Magnum Mophtologicum''".<ref>Cioculescu, pp.64–65</ref> Also featured were Caragiale's first jibes against the [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Symbolist movement]], including lampoons of Bacalbașa's former patron, Alexandru Macedonski.<ref>Cioculescu, pp.63–64, 134–135</ref> Lastly, ''Moftul Român'' taunted some ''Junimist'' colleagues, including Maiorescu—whom it depicted as a libertine and a seducer of schoolgirls.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/mai_avem_azi_un_maiorescu_ii "Mai avem azi un Maiorescu? (II)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 20/2009</ref>
According to one account, Caragiale himself visited Sotir, where he lectured about the causes and consequences of human stupidity.<ref>Felea, p.8</ref> ''Moftul Român'' did host the occasional socialist article, including an unsigned tribute to [[International Workers' Day|May Day]], most likely written by Bacalbașa himself.<ref name="astovcamil">{{ro icon}} [[Al. Săndulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/procesul_stalinist_al_tovarsului_camil "Procesul stalinist al 'tovarășului Camil' "], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 11/1999</ref> The pieces were many times anonymous, and it is occasionally difficult for researchers to distinguish between Caragiale and Bacalbașa's articles. According to Caragiale expert [[Șerban Cioculescu]], the differences are mostly in style and orthographic preference: Caragiale still used the antiquated [[Romanian alphabet|Romanian letters]] ''ĕ'' and ''ê'', while Toni had updated his writing to the latest norms.<ref>Cioculescu, p.43</ref>
In parallel, Toni completed the first collection of ''Moș Teacă'' stories, printed in Bucharest with the subtitle ''Din cazarmă'' ("From the Boot Camp").<ref name="gc1006">Călinescu, p.1006</ref> Addressing an [[Romanians|ethnic Romanian]] readership in [[Transylvania]] and other parts of [[Austria-Hungary]], the cultural journal ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'' introduced Bacalbașa as an active participant to "the discussion on art", and reported that the book "enjoyed an unusually great success" in a Romanian context.<ref name="salonl&a598-599">{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/3630/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_279290_1894_030_50.pdf "Salon. Literatură și arte"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 50/1894, pp.598–599 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
===PSDMR and ''Adevărul Literar'' campaigns=== After prolonged debates and negotiations, the various socialist assemblies fused with each other, creating, in March 1893, the PSDMR. It has been described as Romania's "first nation-wide [[Working class|working-class]] party",<ref>Hitchins, p.378</ref> and called itself "the vanguard of socialism" in Romania.<ref>"Le parti...", p.596</ref> Toni Bacalbașa was not delegated by Bucharest to represent the Sotir circle at the original PSDMR Congress, and ''Moftul Român'' published a piece attacking Nădejde for having organized that meeting behind closed doors.<ref>Felea, pp.6, 8</ref> He may still have been present at that reunion, representing another club.<ref name="ii54">Iacoș, p.54</ref> Toni was also a noted guest at the Sotir meeting acknowledging the party's establishment, addressing a packed hall.<ref>Felea, p.7; Iacoș, pp.54, 59</ref>
His political role was recognized by his peers, who nominated him for the Commission drafting the party program,<ref name="ii54"/> then elected him on the party's governing body (the General Council).<ref name="vd(09)42">Durnea (2009), p.42</ref> Bacalbașa was one of the six people elected by the congress into a ten-member delegation to the [[Second International]]'s [[Zurich Socialist and Labour Congress, 1893|Zurich Congress]], but was replaced at the last minute.<ref>Iacoș, pp.58–59</ref> Meanwhile, superseded by the PSDMR's own press (''[[Lumea Nouă]]'', ''[[Munca]]''), ''Democrația Socială'' closed down.<ref name="pdpdems2"/> Also in 1893, Constantin Mille took over leadership of the republican daily ''Adevărul'', making it the informal PSDMR platform. Toni was appointed as one of the paper's editors,<ref name="cc115">Cosco, p.115</ref> and authored what is probably the first-ever interview in Romanian media history.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/caragiale_n_tradiia_interviului "Caragiale în tradiția interviului"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 9/2005</ref> The other Bacalbașas were also enlisted by ''Adevărul'': Constantin was one of the main editors;<ref name="zocapitala"/> Ioan was famous as the [[gossip columnist]] (and infamous for never using commas).<ref name="ftviata">{{ro icon}} Florentina Tone, [http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/povesti-din-viata-adev-rului.html "Povești din viața ''Adevĕrului''"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418013032/http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/povesti-din-viata-adev-rului.html |date=April 18, 2009 }}, in ''[[Adevărul]]'', December 31, 2008</ref>
As noted by journalist Ilie Ighel in ''Familia'', there was a swift transition from republicanism to socialism, effected when some of the old staff left ''Adevărul''. He wrote: "[instead,] a sinister character emerges, in the person of Anton Bacalbașa, the graduate of two gymnasium classes, along with other unknown celebrities [...]. It is certain that such transitions from one stance to the other have disgusted the cultured public, giving birth to a deep resentment for this sheet that, once taken over by Anton Bacalbașa, did not embrace [[scientific socialism]], [...] but proceeded to insult with brutality all those things that are notable in industry, commerce, finance".<ref name="iisalon296"/> In retrospect, Constantin Bacalbașa also admitted that the socialist takeover was made possible because [[Alexandru Beldiman]], the newspaper's owner, was "weak-willed".<ref>C. Bacalbașa, p.160</ref>
[[File:Dezrobirea Muncitorilor (Lumea Nouă 11, 1895) MI aug73.jpg|thumb|270px|PSDMR propaganda in the magazine ''[[Lumea Nouă]]'', 1895. The female figure represents [[social democracy]], and the [[red flag (politics)|red flag]] is marked ''[[Proletarians of all countries, unite!]]'']] Toni was a noisy presence at ''Adevărul'', and for this reason did not get along with Beldiman. According to one account, he and Beldiman got into a war of nerves, interrupting each other's activities with the sound of bells—moving from standard [[handbell]]s to heavy [[cowbell]]s.<ref name="ftviata"/> Toni was later assigned to lead the ''Adevărul Literar'' cultural supplement, which gave him the opportunity to engage in major debates over literary theory. Călinescu describes enterprise as reflecting "the socialist spirit".<ref name="gc564"/> When Caragiale lost his position as a civil servant and fell back on money earned with his restaurant, Toni attempted to stir an anti-government reaction among the general public. His publicity stunt, taken up by ''Adevărul Literar'', was a faux [[obituary]], announcing that, if stripped of a salary, Caragiale was (as good as) dead.<ref name="cc115"/>
Several sources note that Bacalbașa was a harsh reviewer of literary works, who made sure to point out the flaws of literary debutantes.<ref name="cc114">Cosco, p.114</ref><ref name="grdebutul335">{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/jspui/bitstream/123456789/18758/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_486684_1928_044_0021.pdf "George Ranetti despre debutul său literar"; "Note biografice"], in ''[[Universul Literar]]'', Nr. 21/1928, p.335 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref><ref name="ftscriit">{{ro icon}} Florentina Tone, [http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/scriitorii-de-la-adev-rul.html "Scriitorii de la ''Adevĕrul''"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427072852/http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/scriitorii-de-la-adev-rul.html |date=2009-04-27 }}, in ''[[Adevărul]]'', December 30, 2008</ref> In the end, ''Adevărul Literar'' received contributions from, among others, Demetrescu, Constantin Stere (with the pen name ''Un observator ipohondru'', "A Hypochondriac Observer"), H. Sanielevici, [[Simion Sanielevici]], [[Ion Gorun]] and [[Artur Stavri]].<ref name="ftscriit"/> Also featured, on his debut, was the aspiring humorist [[George Ranetti]], who received the signature ''Namuna'', and who referred to Bacalbașa as "my literary godfather".<ref name="grdebutul335"/>
Bacalbașa's efforts were again mainly dedicated to the promotion of didactic art. The main cultural battle was no longer carried between the PSDMR and ''Junimea'', but between the socialist and non-socialist advocates of didacticism. ''Adevărul Literar'' directed its passion against author [[Alexandru Vlahuță]] and his journal ''[[Vieața]]'', whose pro-didactic agenda was more [[right-wing]] than Mille's.<ref>Călinescu, p.564; Durnea (2009), p.42</ref> Vlahuță was already outraged by Caragiale's unsigned parodies in ''Moftul'', calling them the work of "some stupid parvenu".<ref>Vianu, p.185</ref> His conflict with the Gherea socialists was, according to Călinescu, rather pointless, since Bacalbașa is "only apparently an adversary of Vlahuță's".<ref name="gc564"/> The debate nevertheless grew into a mutual animosity. In one of his letters, Vlahuță feigns shock at the discovery that Toni has judged him to be "talentless".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/cum_se_mpac_literaii_cu_muzicienii_ii "Cum se împacă literații cu muzicienii (II)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 16/2009</ref>
The dispute over such issues grew more heated as others joined in. According to Kirițescu, Toni's debate with Doctor [[Alceu Urechia]], an anti-didacticist, degenerated into "a suburbanite airing of dirty laundry";<ref name="ck46">Kirițescu, p.46</ref> while Cosco writes that their quarrel was "a waste of humor".<ref name="cc115"/> When Gherea was challenged from the left by a pseudonymous author, ''I. Saint Pierre'', Bacalbașa and his journal reacted with vehemence, debating over this issue with Steuerman-Rodion, a more moderate socialist chronicler.<ref name="vdpierre"/> Yet another target for Toni's criticism was the old historian and novelist [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]], who, still grieving for his daughter [[Iulia Hasdeu|Iulia]], allowed himself to be entirely absorbed into the polemic.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ludovic Dauș]], [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/jspui/bitstream/123456789/18826/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_486684_1929_045_0036.pdf "Amintiri despre Haralamb Lecca"], in ''[[Universul Literar]]'', Nr. 36/1929, p.563 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Bacalbașa was widely credited as the winner of this collateral dispute, and even Hasdeu was pleasantly surprised by his talents, recommending him as Romania's only genuine journalist.<ref name="cc115"/>
Toni's socialist disciples prolonged the scandal, publishing an offshoot of ''Moftul'', entirely dedicated to satirizing the anti-PSDMR coalition, and titled ''Putregaiul Român'' ("The Romanian Rot").<ref name="ck46"/> Bacalbașa's political and artistic preoccupations formed the basis for three new books, all printed in 1894. One was dedicated to, and named after, his conference on the topic of "art for art's sake" (''Artă pentru artă'').<ref name="gc1006"/> Another one was a social pamphlet, ''Bătaia în armată'' ("Beatings in the Army").<ref name="gc1006"/> The third was a selection of [[novella]]s, ''Din viața militară'' ("From the Military Life").<ref name="salonl&a598-599"/> Also in 1894, Toni and Radovici made new visits to Ploiești, where they recruited members for the socialist movement.<ref>"Le parti...", p.589</ref>
===1894 scandals=== Together with Mille and other ''Adevărul'' socialists, Toni was openly courting the much larger PNL. In early 1894, he wrote an ''Adevărul'' piece, calling on the PNL to move further to the left, by "openly embracing the democratic ideals."<ref name="vd(09)32">Durnea (2009), p.32</ref> The offer of a liberal-socialist alliance was announced by the PSDMR's own program, but ignored by the PNL; as a result of this attitude, the PSDMR's Diamandy even suggested an alliance with the governing Conservatives.<ref name="vd(09)32"/> Bacalbașa, Mille and Beldiman were all present at a January 1894 conference, which aimed to coalesce the left into a pressure group for [[universal suffrage]]. It reached out to the Radicals and liberal democrats at ''[[Românul]]'' and ''[[Evenimentul]]'' newspapers, and then to independent [[Agrarianism|agrarian]] activists ([[Vasile Kogǎlniceanu]], [[Constantin Dobrescu-Argeș]]), but, a few months later, broke down into competing factions.<ref>Vasile Niculae, "Liga votului universal", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', August 1973, pp.72–73</ref> On January 24, Toni published in ''Adevărul'' a [[Fairy tale|fairy-tale]]-like lampoon directed at the [[King of Romania|Romanian King]] [[Carol I of Romania]] and at his designated successor [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand]], caricatured as the "avaricious" emperor and the repulsive ''Urechilă'' ("Floppy Ears").<ref>{{ro icon}} Anton Bacalbașa, ''Urechilă Moștenitor'', accessible through the [[Marxists Internet Archive]] [http://www.marxists.org/romana/tematica/literatura/index.htm Romanian Literature page]; retrieved March 12, 2012</ref>
A serious scandal erupted in June 1894, when the socialists found themselves targeted by nationalist students mobs, who objected to the PSDMR's alleged snubbing of the Romanians of Transylvania. The demonstrations soon degenerated into an attack on private institutions, including the ''Adevărul'' headquarters. According to the hostile account of Ilie Ighel, this was the public's way of punishing Bacalbașa's [[proletarian internationalism]].<ref name="iisalon296"/> ''Familia'' also reported that the students had originally asked Bacalbașa to tone down his agenda, to which he allegedly replied: "Get out, you dastards!"<ref name="ceenou251">{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/3662/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_279290_1894_030_21.pdf "Ce e nou? Studenții și ''Adevĕrul''"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 21/1894, p.251 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Reportedly, the rioters were violently dispersed by the ''Adevărul'' typographers. The Police intervened in the squabble, and placed the ''Adevărul'' building under armed guard.<ref name="ceenou251"/> Arrest warrants were issued for the ''Adevărul'' staff: Mille and Alexandru Ionescu were taken into custody and released a short while after, whereas Bacalbașa absconded.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/jspui/bitstream/123456789/18029/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_P3441_1894_012_0021.pdf "Știri"], in ''[[Universul Literar]]'', Nr. 21/1894, p.6 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
Mille's group found a friend in Constantin Stere, by then a maverick member of the PNL, who began maneuvering against the PNL's right-wing from the inside. Managing a literary sheet put out by the pro-PNL ''Evenimentul'', Stere supported ''Adevărul'' in its campaign for literary didacticism, and organized rallies of solidarity with the Bucharest socialists. This happened just as Toni was publishing satirical pieces targeting ''Evenimentul'' owner George A. Scorțescu, which left Stere in an awkward position.<ref name="vd(09)42"/> Stere was consequently accused by ''Evenimentul'' of being a spy and a tool for the Conservatives. The incidents were reviewed with caution by ''Adevărul'', whose panelists feared that a Conservative conspiracy was in the making, but Toni also criticized the PNL papers for suggesting the same.<ref>Durnea (2009), pp.33, 42–44</ref>
When Stere challenged Scorțescu to a duel, Bacalbașa covered the affair for ''Adevărul''. Although he condemned Scorțescu's editorial policy, Toni advised Stere to withdraw his demand for satisfaction, or else "all the crooks and vermin will only have to learn how to duel and that's how the press will be banned from taking a stand."<ref>Durnea (2009), pp.36–37</ref> In his column of October 1, when he discussed the Conservatives' decision to expel all "trouble-making" students, he admitted that the complications of the affair surpassed his power of understanding: "I could not say [who is right] anymore, there's a sort of black confusion in my mind".<ref>Durnea (2009), p.44</ref>
The friendship between Bacalbașa and Mille had soured over those months, and Toni soon left ''Adevărul'' for good. It is possible that this rift occurred because of Beldiman, who ceded his stock to Mille without even considering Bacalbașa for a successor.<ref name="ftparinte">{{ro icon}} Florentina Tone, [http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/parintele-ziaristicii-romane-moderne.html "Părintele ziaristicii române moderne"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406070444/http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/parintele-ziaristicii-romane-moderne.html |date=April 6, 2009 }}, in ''[[Adevărul]]'', December 21, 2008</ref> The issue was of interest to the entire socialist movement, since ''Adevărul'' vied for attention with the same niche of the working public.<ref name="110ani12">''110 ani...'', p.12</ref> One of Stere's colleagues, the socialist N. Quinezu, denounced Anton Bacalbașa for being in a conflict of interest, for holding a PSDMR office while still working at ''Adevărul'', and for vetoing funds for the PSDMR sheet ''Lumea Nouă''.<ref name="vd(09)42"/> On September 25, 1894, Bacalbașa presented his resignation from the PSDMR Council.<ref name="vd(09)42"/> He also reconciled with ''Familia'', where he published his [[sketch story]] ''La garda pieții'' ("Guarding the Marketplace", December 1894).<ref name="ablagarda601-603">{{ro icon}} Anton Bacalbașa, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/familia/1894/BCUCLUJ_FP_279290_1894_030_51.pdf "La garda pieții"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 51/1894, pp.601–603 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> ''Adevărul Literar'' went out of business on February 13, 1895,<ref>{{ro icon}} Simona Chițan, [http://www.adevarul.ro/cultura/literar_si_artistic/retro/Ieri_si_azi-_Literarul-prin_filele_vremii_0_465553865.html# "Ieri și azi: ''Literarul'', prin filele vremii"], in ''[[Adevărul Literar și Artistic]]'', April 19, 2011</ref> and Mille found himself expelled from the PSDMR after the Third Party Congress of April.<ref name="110ani12"/>
During that year, Toni was still active in the party, writing for ''Lumea Nouă'' and upholding Gherea's political line. His articles touched a sensitive subject: the Law on Mining, passed by the ''Junimist'' Prime Minister [[Petre P. Carp]], which did away with the PNL's [[protectionism]] and greatly increased foreign investment in the Romanian economy.<ref name="zo(98i)329-330">Ornea (1998, I), pp.329–330</ref> The PSDMR, committed to the Marxist theory on the [[relations of production]], supported the law as a step forward into [[capitalism]], but also criticized it for not allowing a state monopoly on mines.<ref name="zo(98i)329-330"/> Also that year, Bacalbașa dueled with a certain Bogdanovici, having Caragiale as his witness. The event is remembered in literature because Caragiale, using his trademark [[Black comedy|black humor]], called on the duelers to fire their pistols from a distance of ten paces.<ref>Călinescu, pp.493–494</ref>
===Conservative politics and death=== [[File:MilleBacalbasaAdevarul.jpg|thumb|280px|[[Constantin Mille]] (first seated, from left) and the other members of ''Adevărul''{{'}}s editorial staff in 1897, after Toni's departure. [[Ioan Bacalbașa|Ioan]] and [[Constantin Bacalbașa]] stand directly behind Mille]] Eventually, Bacalbașa formalized his split with the socialist party. From 1896, both he and his rival Scorțescu were members of a PNL splinter group, presided upon by lawyer [[Nicolae Fleva]].<ref>Cosco, p.115; Durnea (2009), p.42</ref> He served the "Flevist" cause as a writer for ''[[Dreptatea]]'' daily, then as a public speaker, organizing rallies at Dacia Hall and agitating the public for the reinstatement of [[Ghenadie Petrescu]] as [[Patriarch of All Romania|Metropolitan-Primate]].<ref name="cc115"/> All three Bacalbașas, together with Fleva and the ''Lumea Nouă'' socialists (represented by A. Ionescu), also protested when PNL Prime Minister [[Dimitrie Sturdza]] expelled [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] refugees for having questioned his [[Balkans]] policy.<ref>C. Bacalbașa, pp.196–197</ref> Soon, Toni embarked on an additional venture, creating a satirical magazine named after (and featuring stories with) ''Moș Teacă''. In its first series, the periodical hosted a lampoon piece by the young leftist writer [[Gala Galaction]]<ref>{{ro icon}} Cornelia Ștefănescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/substana_uman "Substanța umană"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 3/2003</ref> and Toni's own satirical portrait of Caragiale as a political opportunist, gravitating between the ''Junimists'' and [[George Panu]]'s Radicals.<ref>Cioculescu, p.23; {{ro icon}} Ion N. Nastasia, [http://www.romlit.ro/i.l._caragiale_orator_i_om_politic "I.L. Caragiale orator și om politic"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 6/2001</ref>
The journalist settled down to a family life, marrying Alexandrina Scărișoreanu (who was ten years his younger).<ref name="gc564"/> He also accepted an offer from Transylvania's ''[[Vatra (Romanian magazine)|Vatra]]'' magazine (co-edited by Caragiale) to set up its satirical supplement ''Hazul'' ("Fun"), but the venture failed to interest the public and was abandoned.<ref>Călinescu, p.564. See also {{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/familia/1895/BAR_FP_PIII155_1895_031_6.pdf "Salon. Literatură și arte"], in ''[[Familia (literary magazine)|Familia]]'', Nr. 6/1895, p.70 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> On March 22, 1898, Bacalbașa began reissuing ''Moș Teacă'', introduced as ''Jurnal Țivil și Cazon'' ("Civilian and Military Newspaper").<ref>Călinescu, pp.564, 728</ref> One of its preferred targets was Mille, referred to in the paper as ''Millu Crocodilu'' ("Mill[e] the Crocodile").<ref name="ftparinte"/> The co-author of such material was Ranetti-Namuna, who arrived there after a stint at ''Lupta''.<ref name="grdebutul335"/>
During 1899, Bacalbașa followed Fleva's group as it merged into the Conservative Party. His presence alongside Maiorescu was recorded with displeasure by the ''Junimist'' [[Ioan Slavici]], as one of the reasons why Conservative politics had become ineffectual.<ref>{{ro icon}} Stelean Boia, [http://www.revista-studii-uvvg.ro/files/revista_IV_4.pdf "Ioan Slavici – ''Tribuna'' și tribunismul în context european"], in the [[Vasile Goldiș West University of Arad]] [http://www.revista-studii-uvvg.ro/ ''Studii de Știință și Cultură''], Nr. 4/2008, p.80</ref> A Conservative cabinet was called to power, with Fleva as the [[Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (Romania)|Agriculture Minister]], and Bacalbașa ran in the [[Romanian general election, 1899|general election of 1899]], earning an [[Ilfov County]] seat in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]].<ref>C. Bacalbașa, p.270; Cosco, p.115</ref> Toni still pursued his literary interests: together with "Constantin Ivan" (the common pseudonym of his two brothers), he wrote the 3-act political [[revue]] ''Pardon!''.<ref>C. Bacalbașa, p.257; Călinescu, p.1006</ref>
This was to be his last known endeavor: on October 1, 1899, having contracted [[bacterial pneumonia]],<ref name="gc564"/> Bacalbașa died, and was buried at [[Bellu cemetery]].<ref>Bezviconi, p.58</ref> Public mourning was taken up by both Fleva and Caragiale.<ref name="cc115"/> According to the former: "Through every sort of trouble, through every storm I ever had to cross into, I felt strong knowing that Anton Bacalbașa was with me. It is to his talent, his heart and his friendship that I owe the best years of my public life."<ref name="cc115"/> The same year, the PSDMR itself disappeared from the scene: [[Ioan Nădejde]] and his "generous ones" faction denounced socialist politics as too feeble for the Romanian context, and joined the PNL, leaving a minority, under [[C. Z. Buzdugan]], [[I. C. Frimu]] and [[Christian Rakovsky]], to establish a more radical workers' party (embryo of the post-1910 [[Social Democratic Party of Romania (1910-1918)|Social Democratic Party]]).<ref>''110 ani...'', pp.12–15; Hitchins, pp.380–381</ref>
==Literary work== [[File:Constantin Jiquidi - Valorosul Căpitan Moș Teacă citește regulat organul nostru 11 feb 1896.png|thumb|290px|[[Moș Teacă]] reading about himself in the eponymous magazine—caricature by [[Constantin Jiquidi]], February 1896]] During his 1890s polemics, Anton Bacalbașa explained at length what his vision of didacticism meant. His stated belief was that: "In all of our works, that which is alive first and foremost is ourselves."<ref name="gc565">Călinescu, p.565</ref> Nevertheless, George Călinescu writes, Toni "was far from pouring socialism over everything", and believed that poetry in particular should be apolitical.<ref name="gc565"/> As early as 1894, [[Avram Steuerman-Rodion]] noted that the ''Adevărul Literar'' editor had been straying away from Dobrogeanu-Gherea's didactic path.<ref name="vdpierre"/>
''Moș Teacă'', which endures as Bacalbașa's best liked series,<ref name="gc564"/> is a tragicomic account of military life. The eponymous hero is a grotesque Army Captain, who is comically illiterate but savage in his treatment of the recruits. The reader never learns his actual name, but only his nickname, literally "Old Man [[Scabbard]]", but also rendered as "Captain [[Scabbard]]"<ref name="abscabbard">Anton Bacalbașa, [http://www.plural-magazine.com/article_captain-scabbard.html "Captain Scabbard (excerpts)"], in ''[http://www.plural-magazine.com/ Plural Magazine] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321152817/http://www.plural-magazine.com/ |date=March 21, 2012 }}'', Nr. 10/2001</ref> (Bacalbașa hints that derogatory nicknames were commonly used by the recruits when referring to their unpopular superiors).<ref name="hgporecle">{{ro icon}} [[Horia Gârbea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/personajele._porecle_i_diminutive "Personajele. Porecle și diminutive"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 7/2012</ref> It is generally held that Toni's anti-hero is in large part inspired by a standard of [[French literature]], in particular by [[Charles Leroy]]'s ''Col. Ramollot'' and [[Henry Monnier]]'s ''[[M. and Mme. Joseph Prudhomme|Joseph Prudhomme]]''.<ref>Călinescu, p.564; Kirițescu, p.47</ref> This interpretation is nuanced by researcher [[Constantin Ciopraga]], who argues: "As a former army volunteer, the future journalist Bacalbașa did not need the French model proposed by Charles Leroy in ''Le Colonel Ramollot''; he was directly familiarized with the [[Prussian virtues|Prussian spirit]] of yesteryear."<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Constantin Ciopraga]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/CIOPnov.html "Proze recente"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', November 2002</ref>
Moș Teacă has lived all his life in the army, having been a drummer boy by vocation.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Horia Gârbea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/pentru_urechile_i_sufletele_personajelor "Pentru urechile și sufletele personajelor"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 2/2008</ref> His obtuse nature greatly disturbs his understanding of civilian affairs: when he is informed that the [[Dâmbovița River]] has swelled, he asks, "Who gave the order for this?"<ref name="gc564"/> He provides his men with incomprehensible advice on how to march, instructs them how to make a polite retreat if the enemy catches them without a weapon, and, while on maneuvers on the [[Prut River]], orders them to combat the [[epizootic]] with a verbal inspection of the cattle.<ref name="abscabbard"/>
Teacă and the other infantry officers are especially violent toward the recruits, and use a wide inventory of corporal punishments, on an advancing scale. In addition to hitting the young soldiers (with their bare knuckles, with sword belts, or with sticks), they force some to run around for hours with a "bitch" (the regimental [[Maxim gun]]) on their back,<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Horia Gârbea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/agresiuni_ncierri_i_arme "Agresiuni, încăierări și arme"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 31/2006</ref> or to hold aim while staring directly into the sun.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Horia Gârbea]], [http://www.revistaluceafarul.ro/index.html?id=482&editie=27 "La cremenal! Avocați și osîndiți"], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 23-24/2008</ref> In ''La garda pieții'', the soldiers react badly to injustice and stage a protest, but their effort is ultimately wasted by intrigues.<ref name="ablagarda601-603"/> Other categories of servicemen are also touched by Bacalbașa's wit. His stories show [[military medicine]] as a grim spectacle: the physicians are either criminally incompetent or sadistic, driving recruits to the brink of suicide.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Horia Gârbea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/personaje_boale_i_doftori "Personaje, boale și doftori"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 37/2007</ref> The elite cavalry (''Roșiori'') show particular restraint in public, but are merciless in dealing with their young subordinates.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Horia Gârbea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/cai_clrei_i_atelaje_hipo "Cai, călăreți și atelaje hipo"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 11/2008</ref>
Army men were generally irritated by Bacalbașa's comedy. Some ten years after the author's death, [[Constantin I. Brătianu|General Brătianu]] commented that Moș Teacă was the stuff of imagination, and propaganda "for the naive".<ref>[[Constantin I. Brătianu]], ''Ce este cu Era nouă în oștire. Studiu retrospectiv'', Albert Baer, Bucharest, 1909, pp.59–62, 101–102</ref> Toni himself probably intended to make Teacă reach beyond the topic of [[antimilitarism]]. As he explained, Teacă might just as well be active in environments other than the boot camp, from the marketplace to the [[Senate of Romania]].<ref name="gc564"/> In order to ridicule his colleagues in the media, Bacalbașa created an alternative character, the self-seeking newspaperman ''Spanachidi'' (said to have been based on a real-life model).<ref name="cc114"/>
Bacalbașa's other humorous works are scattered. Călinescu describes him as a restless "buffoon" and "an unpretentious journalist", but acknowledges that his French wit and verve have raised the level of Romania's media.<ref>Călinescu, pp.564–565</ref> Toni's parodies of Symbolism, published in ''Moftul Român'', are described by Cioculescu as even better than those signed by Caragiale, since they hit closer to "the mark".<ref>Cioculescu, pp.63–64</ref> Many of his other written contributions are [[homograph]]ic [[one-line joke]]s, or samples of [[absurd humor]] in the ''[[épater la bourgeoisie]]'' tradition, while his memoirs record the involuntarily humorous rhyming of a poet-soldier.<ref>Călinescu, pp.564, 565</ref> Călinescu finds them amusing but, in large part, copied from the French prankster [[Alfred Jarry]] ("the technique of ''[[Ubu Roi|Ubuesque]]'' humorists").<ref name="gc564"/> Both Anton and Constantin Bacalbașa were also early pioneers of the Romanian [[epigram]] genre, which the former helped popularize at ''Moftul''.<ref>{{ro icon}} Liviu Grăsoiu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/GRASOIUapr3.html "Cu toată seriozitatea despre epigramă"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', April 2003</ref>
Some of Bacalbașa's writings are of a more restrained nature, and even include somber pieces. A younger colleague, C. Cosco, recalled: "We [journalists] knew that, under his ferocious sarcasm, under his biting wit, he was hiding the sentimentality of a German maiden."<ref name="cc114"/> In his more serious poems, Toni follows the model set by ''Junimea''{{'}}s [[Mihai Eminescu]].<ref name="gc564"/> In a controversial article he wrote in 1890, Toni asserted that Eminescu was a unique genius, who did not fit in with any school of literature.<ref>C. Popescu-Cadem, ''Titu Maiorescu în fața instanței documentelor'', Editura Biblioteca Bucureștilor, 2004, p.224. {{ISBN|973-8369-16-9}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:Stamp 1965 Anton Bacalbasa.jpg|thumb|200px|Anton Bacalbașa on a 1965 Romanian stamp]] Following Toni's death, Alexandrina Bacalbașa remarried, to the Transylvanian literato [[Nerva Hodoș]].<ref>Bezviconi, p.154; Călinescu, p.564</ref> She survived her second husband by several decades. When she died, in 1954, she was buried next to her first husband.<ref>Bezviconi, pp.58, 154</ref>
A final ''Moș Teacă'' [[almanac]] was put out in 1900, featuring the sketch ''Ion prostul'' ("Stupid Ion"), which, although believed by the publisher to be Bacalbașa's work, may in fact be a forgotten contribution by Caragiale.<ref>Cioculescu, pp.43–46</ref> At around that time, [[George Ranetti]] also tried to revive ''Moș Teacă'' magazine, and continued to write humorous pieces in the manner introduced by Caragiale and Toni (a subject-matter that Călinescu has named ''Moftology'').<ref>Călinescu, p.728</ref> ''Moș Teacă'' grew in scope, and began publishing satires of Christianity. These earned it a poor reputation in the media, created a political controversy, and nearly resulted in a trial of Ranetti.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/tribunapoporului/1900/BCUCLUJ_FP_P2514_1900_004_0002.pdf "Depravație morală"], in ''Tribuna Poporului'', Nr. 2/1900, pp.2–3; [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/tribunapoporului/1900/BCUCLUJ_FP_P2514_1900_004_0012.pdf "Din Romania. Dela Senat"], in ''Tribuna Poporului'', Nr. 12/1900, p.1 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Additionally, Ranetti used one of Bacalbașa's final texts as preface to a collection of jokes, which saw print in 1901.<ref>Călinescu, p.1019</ref> Caragiale also revived ''Moftul Român'' for a second series, wherein he continued to poke fun at the Symbolists<ref>Cazimir, pp.101–102</ref> and awarded a special prize to the stupidest literary work sent in for publishing.<ref>[[Ioana Pârvulescu]], ''Lumea ca ziar. A patra putere: Caragiale'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 2011, p.47. {{ISBN|978-973-50-2954-8}}</ref>
The Bacalbașa genre had other significant effects on [[Romanian literature]], and in particular on [[Romanian humor|comedy-writing]]. ''Moș Teacă'' proved influential for the work of other Romanian writers, who were active in the [[interwar period]]: [[Gheorghe Brăescu]], then [[Neagu Rădulescu]].<ref>Călinescu, pp.782, 929</ref> The name itself was virtually turned into a common noun (''un moș teacă''), applied to army men who are thought to display the same characteristics as Bacalbașa's anti-hero.<ref name="hgporecle"/> In [[Romanian cuisine]], the writer's name was given to a ''[[delicatessen]]'' variety of [[smoked ham]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Ioana Mitu, [http://www.zf.ro/dupa-afaceri/inapoi-in-bucataria-traditionala-3781177 "Înapoi la bucătăria tradițională"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', January 21, 2009</ref>
In addition to Kirițescu and Cosco's notes, Toni was the subject of a 1924 monograph by socialist critic [[Barbu Lăzăreanu]], and of a 1938 memoir by his ''Adevărul'' acquaintance [[Izabela Sadoveanu-Evan]].<ref name="gc1006"/> In the 1930s, the aged [[Constantin Stere]] wrote his deceased friend into the autobiographical novel ''În preajma revoluției'', as ''Toni [[Baclava]]''.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Alexandru Burlacu]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/BURLACUi.htm "Modelele prezumtive în romanul lui C. Stere" (I)], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', January 2002; Călinescu, p.761</ref>
After 1948, Bacalbașa's republicanism made him a favorite of the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]]. In the 1950s, his anti-monarchic work was central to the [[Education in Romania|Romanian curriculum]], alongside selected pieces by other hand-picked republicans-socialists ([[N. D. Cocea]], [[Traian Demetrescu]], [[Dumitru Theodor Neculuță]], [[Alexandru Toma]]).<ref>{{ro icon}} Andrei Grigor, Simona Marin, [http://www.revistatransilvania.ro/nou/ro/anul-editorial-2009/cat_view/45-anul-editorial-2011.html "Literatura română în școala anilor cincizeci"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 1/2011, p.31</ref> However, the anonymous ''Moftul Român'' articles which were evidently pro-socialist, and which are most likely Toni's contributions, were attributed to Caragiale by official authors such as [[Camil Petrescu]]. This was a counter-factual effort of transforming the ''Junimist'' writer into a champion of the left.<ref name="astovcamil"/>
