'''Fereydoon Batmanghelidj''' (1930 or 1931 – November 15, 2004) was an Iranian writer. He is best known for his book, ''Your Body's Many Cries for Water'', and his writings related to health and wellness.
==Life and family== Fereydoon Batmanghelidj was born in Iran in 1930 or 1931. He attended secondary school in the United Kingdom, at [[Fettes College]] in Scotland, and later graduated from [[St Mary's Hospital Medical School]] of [[London University]]. He then practiced medicine in the United Kingdom, before returning to Iran.<ref name=wpwro>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A64133-2004Nov19.html |title=Physician Fereydoon Batmanghelidj; Wrote About Water's Healing |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=20 November 2004}}</ref> There he became a wealthy entrepreneur,<ref name=indcol>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/colourful-character-camila-batmanghelidjh-on-her-unique-approach-to-charity-work-1219607.html |title=Colourful character: Camila Batmanghelidjh on her unique approach to charity work |work=[[The Independent]] |date=23 October 2011}}</ref> helping in the development of hospitals and medical centres, and in sports projects, including the Ice Palace ice skating rink in Tehran.<ref name=wpwro />
In 1979, after the [[Iranian Revolution]], he was sent to [[Evin Prison]].<ref name=nytulc>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/21/science/science-watch-doctor-finds-ulcer-remedy-while-in-iran-prison.html |title=SCIENCE WATCH; DOCTOR FINDS ULCER REMEDY WHILE IN IRAN PRISON |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=21 June 1983}}</ref> Following his release in 1982, he moved to the United States.<ref name=wpwro />
He married Lucile,<ref name=wpwro /> a Belgian,<ref name=indcol /> and they had four children: Ardeshir, Babak, [[Camila Batmanghelidjh|Camila]],<ref name=wpwro /> and Lila, who committed suicide while he was imprisoned.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/jan/03/camila-batmanghelidjh-kids-my-family-values |title=Camila Batmanghelidjh: My family values |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=3 January 2014}}</ref> His first marriage ended in divorce. He later married Xiaopo Huang Batmanghelidj.<ref name=wpwro />
He died from complications related to pneumonia on 15 November 2004.<ref name=latadv>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/nov/19/local/me-passings19.2 |title=Dr. Fereydoon Batmanghelidj, 73; Advocated 'Water Cure' |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=19 November 2004}}</ref>
==Medical career==
Batmanghelidj was trained at St Mary's Hospital Medical, and practiced medicine in the United Kingdom before his return to Iran.<ref name=wpwro />
He claimed that he discovered the medicinal value of water in treating the pain of [[peptic ulcer]]s during his detention in prison by treating inmates with water when medication was not available. He advanced this position in a guest editorial in the [[Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology]] in 1983.<ref name=nytulc />
In 1992, he authored ''Your Body's Many Cries for Water''.<ref name=quack>{{cite web |url=http://www.quackwatch.org/11Ind/batman.html |title=Some Notes on Dr. Batmanghelidj's Silly "Water Cure" |work=[[Quackwatch]] |date=20 November 2004}}</ref> In this book, Batmanghelidj asserts that chronic [[dehydration]] is the root cause of most pain and many ailments, opposing the use of drugs to cure conditions that he claimed could instead be addressed by increased water consumption.<ref name=wpwro />
He has claimed elsewhere that water provides energy for the body and brain, by splitting into its component [[hydrogen]] and [[oxygen]].<ref name=quack />
===Criticism===
Batmanghelidj's ideas about water curing all diseases have been criticized as [[quackery]] by medical experts.<ref name="Hall">[[Harriet Hall|Hall, Harriet]]. (2010). [https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/the-water-cure-another-example-of-self-deception-and-the-lone-genius/ "The Water Cure: Another Example of Self Deception and the “Lone Genius”"]. ''[[Science-Based Medicine]]''. Retrieved November 22, 2018.</ref><ref>Fitzgerald, Matt. (2014). [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Bh1bBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT179&lpg=PT179&dq=%22no+one+in+the+medical+establishment+gave+credence+to+fereydoon%22&source=bl&ots=T4NCOPrMN6&sig=LYkbHzag6fVVg2POjzSSl59Xh18&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwitk_zRs-neAhXHKsAKHbonCHMQ6AEwAHoECAAQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22no%20one%20in%20the%20medical%20establishment%20gave%20credence%20to%20fereydoon%22&f=false ''Diet Cults: The Surprising Fallacy at the Core of Nutrition Fads and a Guide to Healthy Eating for the Rest of Us'']. Pegasus Books. {{ISBN|978-1605985602}} "No one in the medical establishment gave credence to Fereydoon Batmanghelidj's half-baked notions. He had taken the whole hydration thing too far."</ref> He also drew criticism for his [[HIV/AIDS denialism]].<ref name="Hall"/> Physician [[Harriet Hall]] has described Batmanghelidj as a "crank who believed dehydration is the main cause of disease. He promoted his Water Cure, which was not based on any scientific evidence."<ref>[[Harriet Hall|Hall, Harriet]]. (2017). [https://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/do_i_really_need_to_drink_200_ounces_of_water_every_day "Do I Really Need to Drink 200 Ounces of Water Every Day?"]. ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]''. Retrieved November 22, 2018.</ref>
His ideas have been criticized by [[Stephen Barrett]], co-founder of the [[National Council Against Health Fraud]] and the webmaster of [[Quackwatch]], on several grounds, including a lack of any documented peer-reviewed research and exaggerated claims about the number of patients treated successfully. He further questions that Batmanghelidj has practiced medicine in the United States, pointing to his lack of registration as a physician. He was licensed as a [[naturopath]].<ref name=quack />
==Books== *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''How to Deal with Back Pain & Rheumatoid Joint Pain'' (1991), Global Health Solutions; {{ISBN|0-9629942-0-0}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''Your Body's Many Cries for Water'' (1992), Global Health Solutions, {{ISBN|0-9629942-3-5}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''Water: Rx for A Healthier, Pain-free Life'' (1997), Global Health Solutions; Cas&Bklt edition, {{ISBN|0-9629942-7-8}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''ABC of Asthma, Allergies and Lupus: Eradicate Asthma - Now!'', (2000), Global Health Solutions, {{ISBN|0-9629942-6-X}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''Water For Health, For Healing, For Life'' (2003), Warner Books, {{ISBN|0-446-69074-0}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''You're not sick, you're thirsty!'' (2003), Grand Central Publishing, {{ISBN|0-446-69074-0}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''Water Cures: Drugs Kill: How Water Cured Incurable Diseases'', (2003) Global Health Solutions, {{ISBN|0-9702458-1-5}} *Batmanghelidj, Fereydoon, ''Obesity Cancer Depression; Their Common Cause & Natural Cure'', (2005) Global Health Solutions; {{ISBN|0-9702458-2-3}}

'''George Aristotle Economou''' (June 24, 1923 – April 2, 2003) was an [[United States|American]] [[optics|optical systems]] expert, who helped set up special cameras to photograph and study the first test of the [[atomic bomb]] in 1945. He was instrumental in the development of the atomic bomb at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory|Los Alamos]], working on the [[Manhattan Project]] under scientific director [[Robert Oppenheimer]].
Born in 1923 in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]], Economou built his first telescope at the age of 12. After studying [[astronomy]] and [[astrophysics]] at [[Harvard University]], his career began at the [[Polaroid Corporation]]. In 1944, he joined the [[United States Army]] and was assigned to [[Los Alamos, New Mexico]], where he helped conceptualize camera [[Lens (optics)|lenses]] used to photograph bomb tests.
At Contraves, he was later involved in the design of ground station optical instrumentation for [[GEODSS]].<ref>Kelso, T.S. [http://celestrak.com/columns/v03n02/ "Real-World Benchmarking"], Satellite Times, November 1996. (mentions Contraves as designer and manufacturer of GEODSS during the period Mr. Economou was Group Vice President)</ref><ref>[http://fedbizopps.info/cbd/archive/1995/11(November)/22-Nov-1995/Jsol019.htm "FedBizOpps request citing Contraves as original developer of GEODSS"]</ref>
Economou officially retired in 1990 as Group Vice President, Optical Instruments for the [[Contraves Goerz Corporation]] in [[O'Hara Township, Pennsylvania]], but continued to work on some of the industry's more high-profile projects, such as consulting for design and construction of the [[Large Millimeter Telescope]].<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/obituaries/20030405economou4.asp Obituary: George A. Economou / Authority on large telescopes<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He died of [[lung cancer]] aged 79 on April 2, 2003, at [[Allegheny General Hospital]].
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

(mentions Contraves as designer and manufacturer of GOEDSS during the period Mr. Economou was Group Vice President) *[http://fedbizopps.info/cbd/archive/1995/11(November)/22-Nov-1995/Jsol019.htm "FedBizOpps request citing Contraves as original developer of GEODSS"] *[http://www.post-gazette.com/obituaries/20030405economou4.asp "Obituary at ''Post-Gazette''"] April 5, 2003. (Describes Mr. Economou's involvement in the Large Millimeter Telescope project)

'''Grace Duffie Boylan''' (February 9, 1861 - March 24, 1935) was an American [[writer]]. She wrote many children’s books, often dealing with diverse races and cultures, like ''Uncle Tom’s Cabin'' (not to be confounded with the same title by [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]]). Other titles include: ''Young Folks'', ''Our Little Eskimo Kiddies: Kids of Many Colors'', ''[[Yama Yama Land]]'', and ''Our Little Cuban Kiddies''.
Her ''[[Thy Son Liveth]]: Messages From A Soldier To His Mother'' appeared in 1918 anonymously.<ref Name="Boylan">{{cite book | last =Boylan | first =Grace Duffie | authorlink =Grace Duffie Boylan | coauthors = | title =Thy Son Liveth: Messages from a Soldier to His Mother | publisher =Little, Brown, and company | date = 1919 | location = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=qe0HAAAAIAAJ&dq=Grace+Duffie+Boylan&client=firefox-a&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 | doi = | id = | page =84 pages }}</ref> It is her account (the following editions were published under her name) of what her son communicated to her about death using [[morse code]] and [[automatic writing]] after his death on the battlefield in France during [[World War I]].
This novel served Director [[Peter O'Fallon]] as base for his movie ''[[A Rumor of Angels]]'' (2001), starring [[Vanessa Redgrave]]. The scenario about a boy who learns to cope with the death of his mother by befriending a grumpy old lady who is being transposed to our times.
Boylan was mother to American [[screenwriter]] and [[U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary]] founder [[Malcolm Stuart Boylan]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barlow|first1=John F.|title=Gracie Duffie Boylan Mini-biography|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0102161/bio?ref_=nm_ov_bio_sm|website=IMDB|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref>

{{Orphan|date=September 2018}}
'''Isabel C. Escobar''' is a professor in the Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering at the [[University of Kentucky]] in Lexington, Kentucky.
Escobar has spent more than 20 years in testing biological stability of distribution systems and developing material chemistry for membranes.<ref name="Cyber">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationalcybersecurityinstitute.org/iwics/interview-with-dr-isabel-escobar/|title=Interview with Dr. Isabel Escobar|date=2015-09-28|work=National Cybersecurity Institute|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Bio">{{Cite web|url=http://web.engr.uky.edu/~iescobar/|title=Welcome|last=Escobar|first=Isabel C.|website=web.engr.uky.edu|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref>
== Education == Escobar attended school at Instituto Pio XI in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil from 1982-1991. She received her PhD, M.S. and BSc in Environmental Engineering from the [[University of Central Florida]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.watertechonline.com/dr-isabel-c-escobar-named-editor-in-chief-of-ida-journal-of-desalination-and-water-reuse/|title=Dr. Isabel C. Escobar named editor-in-chief of IDA Journal of Desalination and Water Reuse|date=2013-07-29|publisher=Water Technology Online|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> She was also a [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) Science to Achieve Results (STAR) Fellow.<ref name="Cyber"/>
== Career == Escobar has been lead principal investigator on 25 federally-funded grants and holds one patent for a breakthrough anti-biofouling feed spacer material. She has edited two books, ''Sustainable Water For the Future: Water Recycling versus Desalination,'' and ''Modern Applications in Membrane Science and Technology'', and has written numerous papers.
Escobar chaired the 2006 [[American Water Works Association]] (AWWA) Desalination Symposium in Honolulu, Hawaii. In 2007, she chaired the [[NAMS]] 2007 Annual Meeting in Orlando, Florida. In 2012, she chaired the NAMS 2012 Annual Meeting in New Orleans, LA. In 2015, she gave a [[TEDx talk]] on Biologically-Inspired Sustainable Water Treatment. In 2016, she co-chaired the ECI Advanced Membrane Technology VII conference.<ref name="Bio"/>
In 2000, Escobar was named Professor of Chemical and Environmental Engineering at the [[University of Toledo]] and interim assistant dean for Research Development and Outreach for the College of Engineering.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aiche.org/chenected/2013/08/women-chemical-technology-isabel-escobar|title=Women in Chemical Technology: Isabel Escobar|website=www.aiche.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref> She has been Professor of Chemical and Materials Engineering at the University of Kentucky since 2015. She is an advisor for the University of Kentucky's Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://shpe.engineering.uky.edu/about-us/|title=About Us |publisher= Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers|language=en|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref> She has been Associate Editor of the ''Environmental Progress and Sustainable Energy Journal'', published quarterly by the [[American Institute of Chemical Engineers]].<ref name="Bio"/> She is Editor-in-Chief of the ''Journal of Desalination & Water Reuse'', published by the [[International Desalination Association]].<ref name="Cyber"/>
== Awards == * Northwest Ohio [[YWCA]] Milestone Award for Education (2009)<ref name="Bio"/> * University of Toledo College of Engineering Outstanding Teacher Award (2009)<ref name="Bio"/> * Toledo 20 Under 40 Leadership award (2009)<ref name="Bio"/> * American Institute of Chemical Engineers Separations Division FRI/John G. Kunesh Award (2012)<ref name="Cyber"/>

{{Orphan|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox Politician |birth_name=James David Duncan |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|11|5}} |birth_place = New York, New York, United States |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |candidate = [[United States House of Representatives]] | opponent = [[Renee Ellmers]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]) | incumbent = [[Renee Ellmers]] | election_date = March 15, 2016 ([[Primary election|Primary]] [[Two-round system|runoff]]) |residence = [[Durham, North Carolina]] |spouse = Betsy Duncan (nee Kirby) |alma_mater = [[Marist College|Marist College,
Poughkeepsie, New York]] |religion = [[Catholic]] |website = http://www.jimfornc.com }} '''Jim Duncan''' (born November 5, 1947) is an American politician who is seeking the Republican party's nomination for [[North Carolina's 2nd congressional district]]. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. ==Early life, education, and business career== Jim Duncan was born the son of a South Carolina native and WWII Sailor turned police officer in New York. Duncan was born New York, New York where his father was serving as a Police Officer. Duncan says he spent the first 12 years of his life in a [[Queens]] housing project, but later moved "uptown" to [[The Bronx]]. His father was originally from [[Anderson, South Carolina]]. Duncan's mother took a job on the wait staff at a [[Howard Johnson's]] in [[New York City]]. Jim grew up in modest circumstances, yet because of the hard work of his parents he was able to focus on building a better life and to live the American dream.{{cite web|title=About Jim Duncan|url=http://www.jimfornc.com/meet_jim|website=Jim For NC}} Dedicated to his studies, Jim Duncan worked his way through school and became the first person in his family to achieve a higher education degree. Graduating from [[Marist College]] in 1969, Jim decided to follow in his father's footsteps and joined the military serving in the Army National Guard for five years. In business, Jim found his home in the emerging high-tech industry. Jim began working in the High Tech equipment leasing and Disaster Recovery Services{{cite web|title=About Jim Duncan|url=http://www.jimfornc.com/meet_jim|website=Jim For NC}} after college. He worked hard and became successful in his field. He was recognized by Fortune magazine as one of America's greatest sales people.{{cite news|title=AMERICA'S BEST SALESMEN They want you to be happy. They know how to make you like them. If you're both lucky, you'll know each other a long time|url=http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1987/10/26/69713/index.htm|publisher=Fortune|date=26 October 1987}} He earned numerous work rewards and Salesman of the year and was further honored by the La Salle Christian Brothers. He is of Irish, Scotch and Russian origins. Jim is a member of the Boys and Girls Club of Durham (NC). ==Political career== ===Political Activism=== Jim is a member of the [[Jesse Helms Center]] and a founding member of the Coalition for American Principles (CAP),{{cite web|title=Coalition for American Principles|url=http://www.capofnc.org/index.php/cap-history|website=Coalition for American Principles}} a non-partisan citizens group devoted to the concept of limited government. Duncan joined the Chatham GOP team and raised the bar by creating a much larger Republican presence in a county dominated by Democrats.{{cite web|title=Jim Duncan: A NC grassroots leader to keep an eye on|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=5193|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} Jim ran for and won the position of Chairman of the Chatham GOP in 2010.{{cite web|title=About Jim Duncan|url=https://about.me/jim_duncan|website=About Me - Jim Duncan}} Duncan had a remarkable positive effect on Chatham County's GOP operation from the beginning. He was a leader in orchestrating a conservative takeover of the county board of commissioners and greater conservative representation on the county school board. In 2013, Jim Duncan considered running for the Second District Congressional seat for the 2014 Election cycle.{{cite web|title=Source: Chatham GOP's Duncan eyeing primary bid against Ellmers|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=6145|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} However, in the fall of 2013, Jim decided not to run against Ellmers.{{cite web|title=Duncan takes a pass on primarying Ellmers|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=6371|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} In January, 2015 local dissatisfaction among Conservatives in the Second District led to rumors and suggestions that Jim Duncan reconsider a run for the seat held by "Big Government Barbie", Renee Ellmers.{{cite web|title="Big Gov't. Barbie" Strikes Again! (PAGING JIM DUNCAN.)|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=10164|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} Jim Duncan publicly denounced{{cite web|title=Chatham County's Duncan spanks Big Gov't. Barbie over amnesty votes|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=10249|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} Renee Ellmer's stance with anti-amnesty legislation.{{cite web|title=Ellmers ringleader of GOP rebels opposing anti-amnesty amendment|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=10244|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} In February 2015, Jim Duncan announced the formation of a "Testing the Waters" committee{{cite web|title=Chatham County Republican Party|url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?id=120333638051654&story_fbid=797990406952637|website=Facebook|publisher=Chatham County Republican Party}}{{cite web|title=NC-02: Jim Duncan is "testing the waters." (It begins?)|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=10593|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} to examine a run for the [[North Carolina's 2nd congressional district]] seat. ===2016 Congressional Candidacy=== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in North Carolina, 2016#Candidates}} In April, 2015, Jim Duncan's team made the announcement that he would seek the 2nd District seat.{{cite web|title=NC-02: He’s in! Duncan done testing waters, ready to tackle Ellmers in 2016|url=http://dailyhaymaker.com/?p=10963|website=The Daily Haymaker|publisher=Brant Clifton}} Worries over Renee Ellmer's move on the "Pain Capable Unborn Child Protection Act" are believed to have moved Jim to action.{{cite news|title=Renee Ellmers Faces Pro-Life Primary Opponent After Sabotaging 20-Week Abortion Ban|url=http://www.lifenews.com/2015/04/17/renee-ellmers-faces-pro-life-primary-opponent-after-sabotaging-20-week-abortion-ban/|publisher=Life News}} == Notes == {{reflist|group="Notes"}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://jimfornc.com/ Jim Duncan for Congress] official candidate site *{{YouTube |id = gZjkkenB1jw |title = Jim Duncan: Why I Run }} – a short biography and motivation for running *{{YouTube |id = EdnemWALTUQ|title = Career Politicians are Chicken }} - Jim Duncan takes a poke at politicians not willing to stand by principles {{DEFAULTSORT:Duncan, James}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:North Carolina Republicans]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:Tea Party movement activists]] [[Category:Marist College alumni]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:21st-century Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American people of Russian descent]] [[Category:Activists from New York (state)]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = James Hadfield<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = 1771-1772<!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | death_date = 23 January 1841 (aged 69-70 years) | death_place = Bethlehem Hospital | death_cause = [[Tuberculosis]] | nationality = [[English people|English]] | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = {{no wrap|Attempted 1800 [[regicide]] of [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]]}} | notable_works = }} '''James Hadfield''' or '''Hatfield''' (1771/1772 – 23 January 1841) attempted to [[assassination|assassinate]] [[George III of the United Kingdom]] in 1800 but was acquitted of [[attempted murder]] by reason of [[criminal insanity|insanity]].
==Biography== Hadfield's early years are unknown but he was severely injured at the [[Battle of Tourcoing (1794)|Battle of Tourcoing]] in 1794. Before being captured by the [[France|French]], he was struck eight times on the head with a [[sabre]], the wounds being prominent for the rest of his life. After return to England, he became involved in a [[millennialist movement]] and came to believe that the [[Second Coming]] of [[Jesus Christ]] would be advanced if he himself were killed by the British government. He therefore resolved, in [[conspiracy (political)|conspiracy]] with [[Bannister Truelock]], to attempt the assassination of the King and bring about his own judicial execution.<ref name="ODNB">Eigen (2005)</ref>
On the evening of 15 May 1800, at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], during the playing of the [[national anthem]], Hadfield fired a [[pistol]] at the King standing in the [[royal box]] but missed. Hadfield was tried for [[high treason]] and was defended by [[Thomas Erskine, 1st Baron Erskine|Thomas Erskine]], the leading [[barrister]] of that era. Hadfield [[insanity defence|pleaded insanity]] but the standard of the day for a successful plea was that the defendant must be "lost to all sense … incapable of forming a judgement upon the consequences of the act which he is about to do". Hadfield's planning of the shooting appeared to contradict such a claim. Due to the [[Treason_Act_1795|1795 Treason Act]], there was little distinction between plotting treason and actually committing treason, thus Erskine chose to challenge the insanity test, instead contending that [[delusion]] "unaccompanied by frenzy or raving madness [was] the true character of insanity". Two [[surgeon]]s and a [[physician]] [[expert witness|testified]] that the delusions were the consequence of his earlier head injuries. The [[judge]], [[Lloyd Kenyon, 1st Baron Kenyon]], at this point halted the trial declaring that the verdict "was clearly an acquittal" but "the prisoner, for his own sake, and for the sake of society at large, must not be discharged".<ref name="ODNB"/><ref>''R v. Hadfield'' (1800) 27 St. Tr. (new series) 1281</ref>
Up to that time, defendants acquitted by reason of insanity had faced no certain fate and had often been released back to the safe-keeping of their families. Parliament speedily passed the [[Criminal Lunatics Act 1800]] to provide for the indefinite detention of insane defendants (and the [[Treason Act 1800]] to make it easier to prosecute people for attempts on the life of the king). Hadfield later inspired further use of pleading insanity several years later during the case of [[Edward Despard|Colonel Edward Despard]]. Hadfield was detained in [[Bethlem Royal Hospital]] for the rest of his life, save for a short period when he escaped. He was recaptured at [[Dover]] attempting to flee to France and was briefly held at [[Newgate Prison]] before being transferred to the new insane asylum Bethlehem Hospital (or Bedlam, as it was known). He died there of [[tuberculosis]] in 1841.<ref name="ODNB"/>
==Fictional accounts of Hadfield's life== Hadfield's story is depicted in the [[BBC TV]] period legal drama series in episode 1 of the third series of ''[[Garrow's Law]]'', in which [[William Garrow]] is portrayed as his barrister - however several changes were made from the generally accepted historical facts.

JM Workshop Ltd (2014-present) }} '''Janice Man''' (born December 29, 1988) is a Hong Kong actress and fashion model. ==Career== Janice Man is an actress and fashion model from Hong Kong and has played leading roles in several Mainland Chinese and Hong Kong movies and TV series, including ''The Graduation Song'', ''The Legend of Zu'', ''[[Helios (film)|Helios]]'', ''[[Cold War 2 (film)|Cold War 2]]'', ''[[Nightfall (2012 film)|Nightfall]]'' and ''[[The Midnight After]]''. Janice Man was discovered by talent seekers on the streets of Hong Kong, and became a professional model since the age of 14. Her modeling career took a sharp turn upwards in 2007 when she participated in television series such as 過渡青春 and movies like ''[[Love Is Not All Around]]''. In 2009, August 13, it was announced she signed the contract with [[Leon Lai]]'s star artist management, A-Music. She later appeared in Hong Kong's Asia Exhibit, Summer Pop Live in HK, and other live concerts. Her fame rose steadily in Asia as she was cast in leading roles in several important films and TV series in Hong Kong and China, working with famous co-stars such as [[Chow Yun-fat]], [[Nick Cheung]] and Korean Movie Star, [[Kim Jae-wook]]. She was also featured in commercials for Opaque, Ipsa, I.T. Group, Bausch & Lomb, Adidas and Forever Mark. Her more recent accomplishments show a slow but steady turn to more film and TV work, with a critically acclaimed performance in ''[[Nightfall (2012 film)|Nightfall]]'' in 2012, starring along [[Simon Yam]] and [[Michael Wong (actor)|Michael Wong]]. In 2011, she won the Best Dressed award at the [[30th Hong Kong Film Awards]]. She was the spokesperson of Dr. Kits Hong Kong in 2011, SK-II Facial Treatment Essence from 2013 – 2014 and Adidas Hong Kong’s Winter Jacket in 2015. She is the spokesperson of Bausch & Lomb (Lacelle Series) (from 2011), IPSA and Forevermark (Diamond Ambassador). ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! English title ! {{Infobox ambassador | honorific_prefix = | name = Joel Lion
יואל ליאון | honorific_suffix = | image = Joel2018.jpg | alt = Ambassador Joel Lion | order = | ambassador_from = Israel | country = Ukraine | term_start = August 2018 | term_end = | predecessor = Eli Belocerkovsky | successor = | president = [[Reuven Rivlin]] |birth_date = 1964 |birth_place = [[France]] |death_date = |death_place = |citizenship = [[Israeli nationality law|Israeli]] |alma_mater = [[The Hebrew University]] }} '''Ambassador Joel Lion''' is an Israeli [[diplomat]], [[Ambassador]] Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the [[Israel|State of Israel]] to [[Ukraine]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/prezident-ukrayini-prijnyav-virchi-gramoti-u-posliv-izrayily-50598|title=President received credentials from the Ambassadors of Israel, Qatar, Belgium and Iceland — Official website of the President of Ukraine|work=Official website of the President of Ukraine|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}} From May 2017 to August 2018, he served as the Chief of Diplomatic Staff of the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Tzipi Hotovely]]. Joel Lion joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1993.https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/jrep/access/462004141.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jun+16%2C+1994&author=ERIC+SILVER&pub=The+Jerusalem+Report&edition=&startpage=12&desc=PRESCHOOL+FOR+DIPLOMATS ==Biography== Joel Lion is the son of Alain Lion and Helene Becher. He was born in 1964 in [[France]] and raised in [[Esch-sur-Alzette]] in [[Luxembourg]]. Mr. Lion is married to Rivka, and is the father of eight children. From September 2016 to October 2017 he served as the Special envoy for Holocaust issues and the return of Jewish assets from the Holocaust era. In that position he worked to coordinate the work between the [https://wjro.org.il/ WJRO] and the State of Israel.http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Israel-WJRO-to-work-to-retrieve-assets-from-Holocaust-era-489843 Before from October 2014 to September 2016, he was Director of the Public & Academic Affairs Department at the Media and Public Affairs Division of the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Jerusalem.
From August 2011 to August 2014, Lion served [[Consul-General]] of the [[State of Israel]] in [[Montreal]], with jurisdiction on [[Quebec]] and the [[Atlantic provinces]], and also as the [[permanent representative|Permanent Representative]] of his country to [[ICAO]], the International Civil Aviation Organisation. Prior to being appointed Consul General in Montreal, he served as the Spokesperson and Consul for Media Affairs{{Cite news|url=https://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Israel-is-inventive-moving-and-spiritual-not-just-about-conflict|title='Israel is inventive, moving and spiritual, not just about conflict'|work=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date=2018-08-15}} at the [http://www.israelpolitik.org/ Consulate General of Israel in New York]. He assumed this post in August 2009, and has been responsible for maintaining direct contact with America’s national and local media in the [[tri-state area]], before New York he served as Deputy Director for the Western European Department at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Jerusalem, and was responsible for political relations with Germany. Previously, he was Counselor, Head of the Public Affairs Department at Israel’s Embassy in Berlin. He also served as Deputy Chief of Mission Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania at the Israeli Embassy in Riga and was Charge D'Affaires for Slovakia at the Israeli Embassy in Vienna.
Before joining the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Joel Lion has worked for the JNF-KKL in Jerusalem, as well as the Ministry of Religious Affairs. Lion served in the Israel Defense Forces and attained the rank of Sergeant-Major in the Artillery Corps. == Special Missions == - In 1999, he became the first Israeli official to partake in the mission of election monitoring with the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. - At the start of the second Intifada in 2001, Mr. Lion operated as Spokesman with the MFA special team in Bethlehem.All but 13 to Leave Church of the Nativity, FOXNews - May 9, 2002: http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,52241,00.html - During operation “[[Cast Lead]]”, he worked as director in charge of the MFA Press Center in Sderot. ==Education== In addition to his diplomatic career, Joel Lion has an extensive academic background. He earned his B.A. in Political Sciences from [[Hebrew University]] in 1988, and received his M.A. in History from the [[University of Latvia]] in 1998.
Currently he is a PhD candidate at the Martin (Szusz) Department of Land of Israel Studies and Archaeology of [[Bar-Ilan University|Bar Ilan University]].
He was ordinate Orthodox Rabbi by Rabbi Dan Channen from Yeshivat [[Shema Yisrael Torah Network|Pirchei Shoshanim]] and by the Chief Rabbi of the city of Holon, [http://www.chabad.info/chabadpedia/index.php?title=אליהו_יוחנן_גוראריה Rabbi Eliyahu Yohanan Gur-Arieh]
In 1995, he completed the International Training Course in Security Policy of the Federal Military Department of Switzerland, in Geneva.
He is fluent in Hebrew, English, French, German, Luxemburgish, Yiddish and has a good knowledge of Russian. == Publications == *''The Trees Sing'', A Sourcebook for Tu Bi-Shevat, selected by Rabbi Moshe Edelman, edited by Joel Lion, published by the Jewish National Fund 1992 * [http://jta.org/news/article/2009/10/18/1008571/op-ed-whats-really-on-trial-in-the-goldstone-report ''What is really on trial in the Goldstone Report''] * [http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=879968&category=OPINION#ixzz0kcC5lmAV ''Israel is ready for peace'', by Joel Lion, [[Albany Times Union]], December 19, 2009] * [http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/01/14/1010191/op-ed-hoping-for-a-reconciliation-between-friends ''Hoping for a reconciliation between friends'', by Joel Lion, [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency|JTA]], January 14, 2010 ] *[http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2009/12/06/2009-12-06_it_takes_two_to_forge_a_lasting_mideast_peace.html#ixzz0kcAegLng ''It takes two to forge a '''Keith Wallace''', M.S. Oenology and Viticulture ([[University of California, Davis]]) is the wine [[columnist]] for ''[[The Daily Beast]]''.<ref name="thedailybeast">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/author/keith-wallace/|title=Keith Wallace - The Daily Beast|publisher=thedailybeast.com|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> He founded the [[Wine School of Philadelphia]].
Previously he served as an executive chef and a journalist for [[National Public Radio]], as well as a [[winemaker]] and wine consultant in the United States and Italy.<ref>http://citypaper.net/articles/2007/04/12/class-act</ref> He has contributed to ''Philadelphia Magazine'', ''Philadelphia Style'', and ''Barron's New Wine Lovers Companion'', among other publications, and also created the "Philly Uncorked" show for www.philly.com.
His food and wine book ''Corked & Forked: Four Seasons of Eats and Drinks'' was published by Running Press in 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.runningpress.com/book/ebook/corked-amp-forked/9780762443659| title = Corked & Forked| publisher = Running Press| accessdate = 2017-01-06}}</ref>
==Controversy== The Wine School of Philadelphia received national press attention in 2009 when the [[WWE]] challenged its trademark application with the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office for the mark, "Sommelier Smackdown".<ref name="winespectator">{{cite web|url=http://www.winespectator.com/webfeature/show/id/41062|title=Wine Spectator - Low Membership Price!|publisher=winespectator.com|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> Litigation surrounding the school's intellectual property rights is ongoing.
Also in 2009, the Wine School and founder Keith Wallace were featured on NPR's ''[[All Things Considered]]''<ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=120846050|title=Wine: To The Glass From The Factory : NPR|publisher=npr.org|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> as a result of Wallace's controversial article published in ''The Daily Beast'', "How Wine Became Like Fast Food".<ref name="thedailybeast2">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-11-03/how-wine-became-like-fast-food/|title=How Wine Became Like Fast Food - The Daily Beast|publisher=thedailybeast.com|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.vinology.com/ The Wine School Website] * [http://www.wineclass.net/ The Wine School Blog]

A '''Chuvash''' is a member of the [[Chuvash people]], an ethnic group living in [[Russia]]. === Leaders and politicians === [[File:ЭльменьДС.jpg|thumb|Daniil Elmen]] *[[Vakrim]] (15th century) - Chuvash noble who left [[Golden Horde]] to become a vassal of [[Vasily II of Moscow|Vasily the Blind]]. *[[Mĕtri Căvaš]] (16th century) - hero of the [[siege of Kazan]]. Descendant of [[morza|mărsa]] [[Vakrim]], ancestor of [[Gavrila Derzhavin]]. *[[Kamaj]] (16th century) - Chuvash [[morza|mărsa]] at the service of [[Khan of Kazan]] who defected to the Russian side. *[[Aransajpik]] (17th century) - Chuvash noble at Russian service who was granted 300 [[Obsolete_Russian_units_of_measurement#Area|desiatinas]] of land around Şĕrpü ([[Tsivilsk]]). *[[Daniel Elmen|Daniil Elmen]] (1885–1932) - Chuvash statesman, first leader of [[Chuvash Autonomous Oblast|Chuvash autonomy]] in [[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics|Soviet Russia]]. *[[Nikolay Fyodorov (politician)|Nikolay Fyodorov]] (b. 1958) - former president of [[Chuvashia Republic|Chuvashia]].
=== Military figures === [[File:Vasily Chapaev.gif|thumb|Vasily Chapayev]] *[[Iskej Pajtulĕ]] (17th century) - Chuvash poet, [[ataman]] (colonel) in the army of [[Stenka Razin]]. *[[Vasily Chapayev]]
=== Religious figures === *[[Valĕm Huşa]] (12th century) - [[Volga Bulgaria|Volga Bulgar]] [[Wali|Muslim saint]], highly revered by Chuvashes. *[[Mehmet Huşa Celepi]] (16th century) - Chuvash [[Converts to Islam|convert to Islam]], [[hajji]] (religious pilgrim) and scholar. *[[Nikita Bichurin]] (1777–1853) - [[Eastern Orthodoxy|Christian]] [[archimandrite]], orientalist. (perhaps quarter-Chuvash)
== Academic figures == [[File:I Y Yakovlev.jpg|thumb|Ivan Yakovlev (educator).]] === Educators === * [[Ivan Yakovlev (educator)|Ivan Yakovlev]] (1848–1930) - Chuvash patriarch, inventor of modern Chuvash alphabet. * [[Gennady Volkov (educator)|Gennady Volkov]] (1927-2010) — Chuvash educator, Academician of the Russian Academy of Education, founder of the ethnopedagogics.
=== Linguists === *[[Atner Husankaj]] (b. 1948) - linguist and philologist, first president of [[Chuvash National Congress]]. Son of writer [[Petĕr Husankaj]].
=== Journalists === *[[Nikolai Yut]] - Chuvash writer, folklorist and literary critic.
== Cultural figures ==
<!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[File:Gennadiy Aygi.jpg|thumb|180px|Gennadiy Aygi]] --> === Actors and actresses === *[[Tany Youne]] (1903–1977) - first Chuvash theater actress, the first Chuvash film actress. *[[Boris Markov]] - actor, famous music director, People's Artist of the Russia and [[Chuvash ASSR]].
=== Architects === *[[Pyotr Yegorovich Yegorov|Pyotr Yegorov]] (1731–1789) - author of the railing of [[Summer Garden]].
=== Ballet dancers === *[[Nadezhda Pavlova]] (b. 1956) - famous ballet dancer, [[People's Artist of the USSR]].
=== Musicians === *[[Alexey Aygi]] (b. 1971) - musician, son of [[Gennadiy Aygi|Gennady Aygi]].
=== Painters === *[[Nikolai Ovchinnikov]] (1918–2004) - [[People's Painter of the RSFSR]] and [[People's Painter of Chuvashia|Chuvashia]]. *[[Praski Vitti]] (b. 1936) - Chuvash painter and illustrator.
=== Sculptors === *[[Gerasim Pileš]] (1913–1994) - writer, playwright, sculptor and [[graphicist]].
=== Writers and poets === [[File:МихаилСеспель.gif|thumb|Mišši Śeśpĕl]] *[[Emine (Chuvash poet)|Emine]] (19th century) - most famous Chuvash woman poet. *[[Konstantin Vasilyevich Ivanov|Kĕştenttin Ivanov]] (1890–1915) - outstanding poet, author of "[[Narspi (poem)|Narspi]]". *[[Mišši Śeśpĕl]] (1899–1922) - pioneer of Chuvash [[syllabotonic poetry]]. *[[Dimitri Isayev (writer)|Dimitri Isayev]] (1905–1930) - prolific writer and literary critic. *[[Ille Toktash|Ille Tuktaš]] (1907–1957) - Chuvash writer, poet and [[folkloristics|folklorist]], author of the [[National Anthem of the Chuvash Republic|anthem of Chuvashia]]. *[[Anatoly Serep|Anat Serep]] (1920–2003) - [[World War II]] veteran, writer. *[[Alexander Artemiev]] (1924–1998) - people's poet, writer and translator. *[[Arkady Malov]] (1928–1995) - Chuvash writer, journalist and translator. *[[Gennadiy Aygi|Gennady Aygi]] (1934–2006) - famous poet and translator, father of Russian [[surrealism|surrealist]] poetry. *[[Boris Căntăk]] (b. 1960) - talented writer, playwright and poet. *[[Vasley Mitta]] (1908–1957) - poet and translator.
== Other figures == === Cosmonauts === *[[Andrian Nikolayev|Andriyan Nikolayev]] (1929–2004) - third Soviet [[cosmonaut]], fifth man in space.
=== Sportspersons === *[[Svetlana Chirkova-Lozovaya]] (b. 1945) - fencer, two times olympic champion in foil team competition ([[1968 Summer Olympics]] in [[Mexico City]] and [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in [[Munich]]). *[[Olimpiada Ivanova]] (b. 1970) - race walker, silver medalist of [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]]. *[[Irina Kalentyeva]] (b. 1977) - professional [[mountain bike racing|mountain bike racer]], bronze medalist of [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in [[Beijing]].
== See also == * [[Chuvash Wikipedia]] * [[ChuvashTet]] * [[Chuvash National Museum]] * [[Society for the study of the native land (Chuvashia)|Society for the study of the native land]] * [[Chuvash National Congress]]

page.title: List of The X Factor finalists (Australia season 1)

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The X Factor'' finalists (Australia season 1)}} The [[The X Factor (Australia season 1)|first season]] of ''[[The X Factor (Australian TV series)|The X Factor Australia]]'' was broadcast on [[Network Ten]].<ref name="premiere"/> It premiered on 6 February 2005 and ended on 15 May 2005.<ref name="premiere">{{cite news|last=Tuohy |first=Wendy |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/TV--Radio/The-search-for-it/2005/02/02/1107228755628.html |title=Looking for that certain something |work=[[The Age]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]] |date=3 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65MYwiziK?url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/TV--Radio/The-search-for-it/2005/02/02/1107228755628.html |archivedate=11 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="end">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/RampB-group-wins-X-Factor/2005/05/15/1116095853635.html |title=R&B group wins X Factor |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |publisher=Fairfax Media |date=15 May 2005 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AYlwpXm3?url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/RampB-group-wins-X-Factor/2005/05/15/1116095853635.html |archivedate=9 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Each category was mentored by one of the show's three judges [[Mark Holden]], [[Kate Ceberano]] and [[John Reid (music manager)|John Reid]].<ref name="end"/> Holden mentored the Groups, Ceberano was given the 16-24s and Reid had the Over 25s.<ref name="end"/> [[Random (band)|Random]] were declared the winners, with Holden emerging as the winning mentor.<ref name="end"/>
==16-24s== ===Jacob Butler=== {{main|Jacob Butler}} Jacob Butler was a 22-year-old contestant from [[Mount Gambier, South Australia]], who was dubbed the "Rock kid" of ''The X Factor''. He left the show voluntarily after he and Harder were in the bottom two. Butler later became a contestant on the [[Australian Idol (season 5)|fifth season]] of ''[[Australian Idol]]'' and progressed through to the top 12. He placed eighth in the competition. Since Idol, Jacob has released his debut record "Reason" in Germany and other countries across Europe. The album was released in Australia and New Zealand in August 2013.
===Vincent Harder=== {{main|Vince Harder}} Vince Harder was a 22-year-old contestant from [[Bondi, New South Wales]], who placed third in the competition.
===Gemma Purdy=== Gemma Purdy was a 16-year-old contestant from [[Nunawading, Victoria]].
==Over 25s== ===Russell Gooley=== Russell Gooley was a 27-year-old contestant from [[Narrogin, Western Australia]]. He was the runner-up of the season. He was born in western australia.<ref name="end"/>
===Roslynn Mahe=== Roslynn Mahe was a 30-year-old contestant from [[Granville, New South Wales]].
===Janie Shrapnel=== Janie Shrapnel was a 47-year-old contestant from [[Samford, Queensland]].
==Groups== ===The Brothership=== The Brothership was a group, which consisted of the three Philippou brothers from [[South Australia]], George (aged 33), Adam (aged 30) and Michael (aged 29). They went through many different names during ''The X Factor'', including 49 Sheriff, Phillipo and The Phillipo Brothers, until they settled on The Brothership. The three brothers had previously recorded under the name of [[Universal (band)|Universal]].
===Kaya=== Kaya was a group, which consisted of Alexandra "Alexi" Kaye (aged 29) from [[Bondi Junction, New South Wales]], Juleiaah Boehm (aged 23) from [[Camperdown, New South Wales]], Sally Stevens (aged 25) from [[Bondi, New South Wales]], and Emma Deans (aged 22) from [[Balmain, New South Wales]].
===Random=== {{main|Random (band)}} Random was an [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] vocal group from [[Queensland]], which consisted of Xylocaine "XY" Latu (born 13 January 1979 in [[Tonga]]) from [[Logan Central, Queensland|Logan Central]], Andy-Iese "Jesse" Tolo-Paepae (born 19 January 1984 in Australia) from [[Kingston, Queensland|Kingston]], Wayne Tauvao (born 8 December 1985 in [[New Zealand]]) from Queensland, Tasesa Junior "TJ" Tauvao (born 31 May 1988 in New Zealand) from Kippa-Ring, and Donald Tauvao (born 12 October 1988 in [[Western Samoa]]) from [[Redcliffe, Queensland|Redcliffe]]. Random were announced the winners of the season on 15 May 2005 and received a recording contract with [[Sony Music Australia]].<ref name="end"/>

page.title: List of cultural depictions of Wild Bill Hickok

revision.text:
{{Main|Wild Bill Hickok}}
'''Wild Bill Hickok''' (1837–1876), lawman, gunfighter and gambler, of the American [[Wild West]] has been depicted many times and in many forms of media. It is difficult to separate the truth from fiction about Hickok who was the first "[[dime novel]]" hero of the western era, with his exploits presented in heroic form, making him seem larger than life. In truth, most of the stories were greatly exaggerated or fabricated by both the writers and himself. Along with the frontiersman [[Davy Crockett]], Hickok also became one of the first [[comic book]] heroes.
== Television and Radio == *Portrayed by [[Guy Madison]] in the 1951–58 television series ''[[The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok]]'', and the concurrent Mutual Broadcasting radio series of the same title, 271 half-hour programs originally broadcast from 1951–54. *Played by [[Lloyd Bridges]] in a 1964 episode of the television anthology ''[[The Great Adventure (U.S. TV series)|The Great Adventure]]''. *In a ''[[Quick Draw McGraw]]'' cartoon, a number of people are shown fleeing in terror from the gunfire of the notorious gunslinger, Wild Bill Hiccup. In actuality, his gun kept going off because he couldn’t control his hiccups. *Portrayed by [[Josh Brolin]] in the 1989–92 television series ''[[The Young Riders]]''. *[[Legends of the Hidden Temple]] had an episode entitled "Wild Bill Hickok and the Dead Man's Hand." *Portrayed by William Russ in episode 1.06 of the 1995 television series ''[[Legend (TV series)|Legend]]'', "The Life, Death and Life of Wild Bill Hickok". The episode depicts him faking his own death so that he can retire peacefully. *Portrayed by [[Gerard Buehler]] in the 1998 TV documentary series ''[[Gunfighters of the West]]'' narrated by [[Brian Dennehy]] *''[[Histeria!]]'' featured Hickok in the episode "North America"; he appears in a sketch where [[List of Histeria! characters#Lydia Karaoke|Lydia Karaoke]] hosts a game show in which her contestants must guess Hickok's occupation. *Dramatized in the [[HBO]] series ''[[Deadwood (TV series)|Deadwood]]'', in which he is portrayed by [[Keith Carradine]] (2004). *In the television film ''[[Doctor Who (film)|Doctor Who]]'', the 8th incarnation of the Doctor dons a costume of Wild Bill,{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} found in a hospital locker room. Subsequent depictions of the Doctor's 8th incarnation have been shown to wear this costume.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} *In an episode of the [[Fox News Channel]] documentary series ''[[Legends and Lies: The Real West]]'' entitled "Wild Bill Hickok: Plains Justice" (season 1, episode 3, original airdate April 19, 2015), actor [[Brian Merrick]] (who bears a striking resemblance to the historical figure) portrays Hickok. [[Devin Albert]] portrays Hickok as a young boy. *Some episodes of ''[[Woody Woodpecker]]'' show a parody called "Wild Bill Hiccup", who always hiccups when saying his own name.
== Films == *Played by [[William S. Hart]] in the 1923 film ''[[Wild Bill Hickok (film)|Wild Bill Hickok]]'' *Played by [[Gary Cooper]] in the 1936 film ''[[The Plainsman]]'', featuring [[Jean Arthur]] as [[Calamity Jane]] and directed by [[Cecil B. DeMille]] *In [[The Three Stooges]] short ''Goofs and Saddles'' (1937) [[Moe Howard]]'s character is known as "Wild Bill Hiccup". *Played by [[Wild Bill Elliott]] in the 1938 [[Serial (film)|serial]] ''[[The Great Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok]]'' *Played by [[Wild Bill Elliott]] in the 1940 film ''[[Prairie Schooners]]'' *Played by [[Wild Bill Elliott]] in the 1940 film ''[[The Wildcat of Tucson]]'' *Played by [[Roy Rogers]] in the 1940 film ''[[Young Bill Hickok]]'', directed by [[Joseph Kane]] *Played by [[Richard Dix]] in the 1941 film ''[[Badlands of Dakota]]'' *Played by [[Bruce Cabot]] in the 1942 film ''[[Wild Bill Hickok Rides]]'' *Played by [[Howard Keel]] in the 1953 film ''[[Calamity Jane (film)|Calamity Jane]]'' *Played by [[Forrest Tucker]] in the 1953 film ''[[Pony Express (film)|Pony Express]]'' *Played by [[Tom Brown (actor)|Tom Brown]] in the 1956 film ''[[I Killed Wild Bill Hickok]]'' *Played by [[Robert Culp]] in the 1963 film ''[[The Raiders (1963 film)|The Raiders]]'', directed by [[Herschel Daugherty]] *Played by [[Don Murray (actor)|Don Murray]] in a remake of 1936 film with the same title ''[[The Plainsman (1966 film)]]'' *Portrayed by [[Jeff Corey]] in the 1970 [[Arthur Penn]] film ''[[Little Big Man (film)|Little Big Man]]'' *Portrayed by [[Charles Bronson]] in the 1977 film ''[[The White Buffalo]]'' *Portrayed by [[Richard Farnsworth]] in the 1981 film ''[[The Legend of the Lone Ranger]]'' *Portrayed by [[Jeff Bridges]] in the 1995 film ''[[Wild Bill (1995 film)|Wild Bill]]'' *Played by [[Sam Elliott]] in the 1995 film ''[[Buffalo Girls]]''. (TV film) *Played by [[Sam Shepard]] in the 1999 film ''[[Purgatory (1999 film)|Purgatory]]''. (TV film)
== Novels == * 1964: ''[[Little Big Man (novel)|Little Big Man]]'' by [[Thomas Berger (novelist)|Thomas Berger]] * 1970: [https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/867704.Under_the_Stars_and_Bars ''Civil War: #5 Under the Stars and Bars''] by [[J.T. Edson]] * 1975: [https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2884029-the-white-buffalo ''The White Buffalo''] by [[Richard Sale (director)|Richard Sale]] * 1978: ''[[The Kent Family Chronicles]]'': ''The Lawless'', Volume VII by [[John Jakes]] * 1980: ''Darlin' Bill: A Love Story of the Wild West'' by [[Jerome Charyn]] * 1981: ''Aces & Eights'' by [[Loren D. Estleman]] * 1982: ''[[Flashman and the Redskins]]'' by [[George MacDonald Fraser]] * 1986: ''Deadwood'' by [[Pete Dexter]] * 1990: ''[[Buffalo Girls]]'' by [[Larry McMurtry]] * 1996: ''The Memoirs of Wild Bill Hickok'' by [[Richard Matheson]] * 1999: ''The Return of Little Big Man'' by [[Thomas Berger (novelist)|Thomas Berger]] * 2004: [https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1463879.And_Not_to_Yield?from_search=true&search_version=service ''And Not to Yield''] by Randy Lee Eickoff * ''A Breed Apart'' by Max Evans
== Comic Books == * [[Classics Illustrated]] No. 121, ''Wild Bill Hickok,'' published by Gilberton Co., Inc., July 1954; interior art by Sal Trapani and Medio Iorio.<ref>William B. Jones Jr., ''Classics Illustrated: A Cultural History, with Illustrations'' (Jefferson, NC, and London: McFarland & Co., Inc., 2002), p. 223.</ref> *Cowboy Western #62 ''Wild Bill Hickok'' 1957 *Young Wild Bill Hickok appears as part of The League of Infinity, a team of teenage heroes from different eras in ''[[Supreme (comics)|Supreme]]'' (1994), written by [[Alan Moore]]. *Hickok has a prominent secondary role in [[Vertigo (DC Comics)|Vertigo]]'s mini-series, ''[[Jonah Hex]]: Two Gun Mojo'' wherein he survived being shot but was buried alive, only to be made into a mindless "[[zombie]]" by the antagonist of the story. *Hickok has a supporting role in the 1997-1998 [[DC Comics]] mini-series ''[[The Kents]]'' as a close friend of Nathaniel Kent, ancestor of Superman's adoptive father.
== Music == * "Deadwood Mountain", [[Big and Rich]] * "Wild Bill Hickup", parody by [[Spike Jones]] * "The Ace of Spades", [[Motörhead]] * "Rhymes of the Renegades", [[Michael Martin Murphey]] * "The Burial Of Wild Bill", [[John Wallace Crawford]], performed by [[Norman Blake (American musician)|Norman Blake]] on ''[[Flower From the Fields of Alabama]]'' * "[[Philadelphia Lawyer (song)|Philadelphia Lawyer]]" by [[Woody Guthrie]] * "Rambling, Gambling Willie", [[Bob Dylan]] * "Wild Bill," [[Blue Highway]]

page.title: List of participants in the Synod of Dort

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2011}} [[File:Arminianism as five-headed monster.JPG|thumb|Arminianism as a five-headed monster, 1618 engraving.]]
Official participation in the [[Synod of Dort]], held in 1618–9 in [[Dordrecht]] in the [[Netherlands]], consisted of different groups: Dutch ministers, church elders, and theologians; representatives of churches outside the Dutch Republic; and Dutch lay politicians. There were 14 [[Remonstrants]] who were summoned, in effect as defendants. There were also some observers, who had no voting status. Listings are usually given according to a traditional ordering for the provinces that begins with Gelderland; for the provincial synods Holland was divided into two, North and South. In the sources both Latinised names and spelling variants occur. Lists of those nominated to participate in some capacity differ from those who signed the final Acts of the Synod. Figures vary a little, but one total given is for 102 official participants.<ref>Martin Mulsow, Jan Rohls, ''Socinianism and Arminianism: Antitrinitarians, Calvinists, and cultural exchange in seventeenth-century Europe'' (2005), p. 38; [https://books.google.com/books?id=E9qBWrLuLsYC&pg=PA38 Google Books].</ref> The outcome of the Synod was the most significant single event in the [[Calvinist-Arminian debate]].
The Dutch members of the Synod were divided up by provincial synods (for the clerics and elders as delegates), or by provinces (for the lay members). Allowing for Holland as exception, the delegates were divided into ten "colleges": one for each of seven provinces, plus [[Drenthe]]; one for theological faculties; and one for the [[Walloon language|Walloon]] churches.<ref>Israel p. 460.</ref>

one of those subscribing to the Canons did not present credentials initially). |Elder of Leeuwarden. Subscriber.<ref name=Schaff485>Schaff, p. 485; [https://books.google.com/books?id=8vt3JbWlmLoC&pg=PT485 Google Books].</ref> |- |Meinardus ab Idzerda |Friesland |Elder of Leeuwarden. ==Dutch lay commissioners== * [[Jacob de Witt]] (treasurer)
The commissioners by province were: *Gelderland and Zutphen: Martinus Gregorius, Hendrik van Essen. *Holland and West Friesland: Walrave de Brederode, Hugo Muys van Holy, Jacobus Boelens, Gerardus van Nieuburg, Rochus van Honaert, Nicholaas Krombout. *Zealand: Symon Scotte, Jacobus van Kampe. *Utrecht: Frederik van Zuylen, van Nieuveld, Willem Herteveld. *Friesland: Ernestus van Aylva, Ernestus ad Harinksma. *Overijssel: Hendrik van Haagen, Johannes van Hemerde. *Groningen: Hieronimus Ysbrants, Efaart Jacob Clant, [[Daniel Heinsius]].
Of these Gregorius, van Honaert, Krombout, and Ysbrands were [[doctor of both laws|doctors of both laws]].<ref name=Staat>{{nl icon}} ''Staatkundige historie van Holland: Benevens de Maandelijksche Nederlandsche Mercurius'' (1774) Volumes 36-39 p. 13–5; [https://books.google.com/books?id=iOE1AAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA13 Google Books].</ref> The list of commissioners later signing the Acts of the Synod is somewhat different.<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=The Creeds of the Evangelical Protestant Churches.|author=Schaff, P.|publisher=Ccel|isbn=9781610250399|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8vt3JbWlmLoC}}</ref><ref name="reformedlayman">{{cite web|url=http://reformedlayman.com/SynodOfDort/SynodOfDortSubscribers.htm|title=Synod of Dort -The Subscribers;|publisher=reformedlayman.com|accessdate=2014-09-26}}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=A Catalogue of an Invaluable and Highly Interesting Collection of Unpublished Manuscript Historical Documents ... The Entire Property of a Gentleman of the Highest Consideration in Holland ... which Will be Sold by Auction, by Mr. Sotheby, at His House, No. 3, Wellington Street, Strand, on Monday, May 30, 1825, and Six Following Days (Sunday Excepted), at Twelve O'clock|date=1825|issue=v. 9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pTRbAAAAQAAJ|page=112}}</ref><ref name="reformationfiles">{{cite web|url=http://www.reformationfiles.com/files/displaytext.php?file=dordrechtanae05.html|title=reformationfiles.com|publisher=|accessdate=2014-09-26}}</ref>
==Remonstrants== A number of prominent [[Remonstrant]] ministers were cited to appear before the Synod, around 10% of the 200 identified Remonstrants at that time in the Dutch Reformed Church. Of those, a number were deprived of their church posts before the proceedings, which formed the latter part of the political and religious struggle that had been triggered in 1618, and which came to a head after the Synod closed. Only three Remonstrants were among the delegates (from Utrecht, two ministers and a church elder). [[Simon Episcopius]] emerged as leader of the group of Remonstrants who were summoned. His efforts to secure participation in the debates of the Synod for the group failed after extensive procedural discussion; the summoned Remonstrants were, however, required to remain in Dordrecht. With one exception they refused to subscribe to the required declaration at the end of the Synod, were expelled from the Church, and banished. In total around 70 Remonstrant ministers were banished in the aftermath of the Synod.
[[File:Idea Belgicarum Provinciarum Confaederatarum.jpg|thumb|Allegorical engraving of the Dutch Republic as a ship from 1620, with the [[Stadtholder]] Maurice at the helm.<ref name="xs4all">{{cite web|url=http://pvrooden.home.xs4all.nl/Jo/2011b.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415124144/http://pvrooden.home.xs4all.nl/Jo/2011b.htm |archive-date=2012-04-15 |dead-url=yes |title=Imagining the Synod of Dordt and the Arminian Controversy|accessdate=2015-04-10}}</ref>]]
The 14 Remonstrants banished by the Synod were:
*Gelderland: Bernerus Wezekius, Henricus Hollingerus. *South Holland: Simon Episcopius, [[Iohannes Arnoldi Corvinus]], Bernardus Dwinglonius, Eduardus Popius, Theophilus Rickwaerdius. *North Holland: Phillippus Pinakerus, Dominicus Sampa. *Utrecht: Isaacus Frederici, Samuel Neranus. *Overijssel: Thomas Goswinus, Assuerus Mathisius. *Walloon churches: [[Carolus Niellius]].
(These are the [[Latinised name]]s as given, correcting two spellings.)<ref name="truecovenanter">{{cite web|url=http://www.truecovenanter.com/gospel/synod_of_dort.html|title=TrueCovenanter.com: The Judgment of the Synod Holden at Dort, Concerning the five Articles: As also their sentence touching Conradus Vorstius.|author=The Synod of Dort|publisher=truecovenanter.com|accessdate=2014-09-26}}</ref> Apart from the Utrecht representative ministers who were Remonstrants–Frederici and Naeranus–these clergy were therefore not full participants in the Synod at any point.
A baseline list of 13 names in ''Historie der Remonstranten'' (1774) by Jacobus Regenboog is of those Remonstrants who were summoned (and omitting the delegates Frederici and Naeranus from the Utrecht provincial synod):
*Gelderland: Henricus Leo of Bommel, Vezekius of Egteld, Hollingerus of Grave. *South Holland: Episcopius, Arnoldi and Dwinglo of Leiden, Poppius of Gouda, Rykewaard of Brielle. *North Holland: Pynakker of Alkmaar, Sapma of Hoorn. *Overijssel: Gozuinus and Mathisius of Kampen. *Walloon churches: Niellius of Utrecht.<ref>Jacobus Regenboog, ''Historie der Remonstranten, kortelyk vervattende de geschiedenissen der Gereformeerde Christenen, die men Remonstranten noemt'' (1774), p. 13; [https://books.google.com/books?id=WOQ-AAAAcAAJ&pg=RA1-PA13 Google Books].</ref>
It was Henricus Leo who was the sole Remonstrant of these summoned who signed the Act of Cessation (''acte van stilstand'') as required by the Synod, and escaped banishment.<ref>[http://www.grotius.huygens.knaw.nl/path/deel_4/1586/ in note 17.] {{nl}}</ref> His absence from the first list gives numbers that tally.
There is a longer listing in the works of John Hales of those Remonstrants who were cited by the Synod (21 names, but 20 if Joannes Arnoldi and Corvinus are duplicates); this list includes names of ministers who were by other means removed from their posts. The breakdown by provinces is:<ref>{{la icon}} John Hales, [[Peter Gunning]], [[John Pearson (bishop)|John Pearson]], ''Golden Remains, of the Ever Memorable Mr. John Hales'' (1688), p. 553; [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZEk3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA553 Google Books].</ref>
*Gelderland: Leo, Wezekius, Holderingus. *South Holland: Adrianus Bozzius, [[Nicolaus Grevinchovius]], Episcopius, Arnoldi, Poppius, Rickwardus. *North Holland: Joannes Geysteranus, Sapma. *Overijssel: Goswinius, Mathisius. *Walloon churches: Simon Goulartius, Niellius. *Utrecht: [[Utenbogardus]], Corvinus, Duinghonius, Pinakerus, Neranus, Friderici.
Goulartius ([[Simon Goulart the Younger]] of Geneva, 1575–1628) the Remonstrant was the son of [[Simon Goulart of Senlis]] (1543–1628).<ref>K. A. E. Enenkel, Jan L. de Jong, Jeanine Landtsheer, Alicia Montoya, ''Recreating Ancient History: episodes from the Greek and Roman past in the arts and literature of the Early Modern Period'' (2001), p. 226; [https://books.google.com/books?id=r8pmdjEmiA8C&pg=PA226 Google Books].</ref> Though summoned he had already been dismissed from his post.<ref>{{nl icon}} [http://www.historici.nl/retroboeken/blnp/#source=3&page=144&size=800&accessor=accessor_index ''Biografisch lexicon voor de geschiedenis van het Nederlands protestantisme'']</ref>
==Foreign representatives== There were 27 delegates who attended from outside the Dutch provinces.<ref name=MethRev/><ref>[https://archive.org/stream/newschaffherzog29haucgoog#page/n514/mode/2up ''New Schaff-Herzog Encyclopedia'', article Dort, Synod of].</ref> Two replacements were made during the Synod.

S.|last=Cranfield}}</ref> Addressed as 'bishop' throughout the synod, and distinguished by his seat being provided with an episcopal canopy. |- |[[Joseph Hall (bishop)|Joseph Hall]] (1574–1657) |Withdrew because of illness. |- |[[Thomas Goad]] (1576–1638) |Goad replaced Hall who became ill. |- |[[John Davenant]] (1576–1641) | |- |[[Samuel Ward (scholar)|Samuel Ward]] (1572–1643) | |- |[[Walter Balcanqual]] (1586–1645) |Balcanqual was a priest of the Church of England, but officially was there as representative of the Church of Scotland.<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=1151|title=Balcanquhall, Walter|last=Coffey|first=John}}</ref> |}
===Imperial delegates=== There was some consideration given to invitations to clergy from Reformed churches in the German principalities and cities of the Empire, with a view to being selective and distinguishing among types of nominally Calvinist church.<ref>Richard Watson, Nathan Bangs, ''A Biblical and Theological Dictionary'' Volume 1 (1832), p. 948; [https://books.google.com/books?id=LcJzS1HTU-kC&pg=PA948 Google Books].</ref> Invitations were issued to: the [[Electoral Palatinate|Palatinate]], [[Brandenburg]], [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel|Hesse-Kassel]], [[Nassau (state)|Nassau]], [[East Friesland]], [[Hanau]]. [[Anhalt]] was excluded.<ref name="James Isaac Good">[[James Isaac Good]], ''The Origin of the Reformed Church in Germany'' (1887), p. 407; [https://archive.org/stream/originofreformed00good#page/n433/mode/2up archive.org].</ref> [[John Sigismund, Elector of Brandenburg]] declined to send a delegation; the Calvinist–Lutheran relationship in Brandenburg was fragile, and a diplomatic excuse was made. It was later alleged that Anhalt was not invited, for fear that the delegation would be pro-Remonstrant.<ref>Milton, p. xviii note 2.</ref>
