{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{use Indian English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox police officer |name = Sanjiv Bhatt |image = |caption = |currentstatus= Removed from Service |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1963|12|21|}} |birth_place = [[Bombay]], India |allegiance = [[Indian Police Service]] |department = |service = [[India]] |serviceyears = |rank = |awards = |relations = Shweta Bhatt (wife) |almamater = [[IIT Bombay]] |laterwork = }} '''Sanjiv Bhatt''' is a former [[Indian Police Service]] officer from [[Gujarat]]. He is known for his role in filing an affidavit in the [[Supreme Court of India]] against the [[Chief Minister]] of the [[Government of Gujarat]], [[Narendra Modi]], concerning Modi's alleged role in the [[2002 Gujarat riots]]. He falsely claimed to have attended a meeting, during which Modi allegedly asked top police officials to let Hindus vent out their anger against the Muslims. However, the Special Investigation Team appointed by the Supreme Court of India concluded that Bhatt did not attend this meeting, and dismissed his allegations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-29/news/38904835_1_sanjiv-bhatt-sanjeev-bhatt-zakia-jafri |title=Sanjiv Bhatt did not attend Narendra Modi's Feb 2002 meeting, says SIT |newspaper=Economic Times |date=29 April 2013}}</ref>
In 2015, Bhatt was removed from the police service, on the ground of "unauthorised absence". In October 2015, the Supreme Court quashed Bhatt's plea for constituting a special investigation team (SIT) for cases filed against him by Gujarat Government. The court lifted a stay on his trial in these cases and asked him to face prosecution. The court observed that, "Bhatt was in active touch with leaders of rival political party, was being tutored by NGOs, was involved in politics and activism of creating pressure, even upon 3-judge bench of this court, amicus and many others".<ref>{{cite news|title=Supreme Court quashes Sanjiv Bhatt’s plea, says attempt to influence court through politics and activism|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/2002-gujarat-riots-sc-dismisses-ex-ips-officer-sanjiv-bhatts-petition-against-amit-shah/|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>
== Early life ==
Sanjiv Bhatt is a [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JQS8yMDEyLzA1LzA5I0FyMDAxMDA%3D|location=Ahmedabad|title=Sanjiv Bhatt the pivot in case against Modi|date=2012-05-09|publisher=[[The Times of India]]}}</ref> He earned an M. Tech. degree from the [[Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay]] in 1985. He is married to Shweta Bhatt.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/bhatt-is-not-new-to-communal-controversies-courts-99922.html |title=Bhatt is not new to communal controversies, courts |publisher=Firstpost |date=5 October 2011 }}</ref>
== Police career ==
Bhatt joined the Indian Police Service (IPS) in 1988, and was allotted the Gujarat cadre. In 1990, as the [[Additional Superintendent of Police]], he detained 150 people in order to control a riot in [[Jamnagar district]]. Prabhudas Vaishnani, one of the detainees, died of [[kidney failure]] a few days later, after being hospitalised. His brother lodged an FIR against Bhatt and six other policemen, alleging that he had been tortured in police custody.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/> Another man, Vijaysinh Bhatti, alleged that he had been beaten up by Bhatt.<ref name="TH_torture_2012" />
In 1996, as the [[Superintendent of police (India)|Superintendent of Police]] (SP) of [[Banaskantha district]], he was accused of falsely framing a Rajasthan-based lawyer in a narcotics case.<ref name="ToI_curious_2011">{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/The-curious-case-of-Sanjiv-Bhatt/articleshow/8069656.cms |title=The curious case of Sanjiv Bhatt |newspaper=The Times of India |date=24 April 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jaipur/Rajasthan-lawyers-accuse-Guj-top-cop-of-conspiracy/articleshow/8094748.cms Rajasthan lawyers accuse Guj top cop of conspiracy]</ref> It was alleged that Bhatt maliciously filed nearly 40 petitions in the high courts of Rajasthan and Gujarat as well as before the apex court to delay action against him. <ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jaipur/Rajasthan-lawyers-accuse-Guj-top-cop-of-conspiracy/articleshow/8094748.cms</ref> The Bar association members have alleged that Bhatt got himself appointed the Gujarat government's officer in-charge for the special appeal petition pending in the SC. They pointed out that Bhatt is using the Gujarat government as a shield to save himself but is also misusing the public money to fight the crimes he committed.<ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jaipur/Rajasthan-lawyers-accuse-Guj-top-cop-of-conspiracy/articleshow/8094748.cms</ref>
He was accused in another custodial torture case in 1998.<ref name="TH_torture_2012">{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article3342659.ece |title=Another case of custodial torture registered against Sanjiv Bhatt |publisher=The Hindu |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
=== 2002 transfer ===
From December 1999 to September 2002, he worked as Deputy Commissioner of Intelligence in the [[State Intelligence Bureau]] at [[Gandhinagar]]. He was responsible for looking after the state's internal security, border and coastal security, and security of vital installations. He was also responsible for the Chief Minister Narendra Modi's security.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/sanjiv-bhatt-the-man-who-took-on-narendra-modi-366957.html |title=Sanjiv Bhatt: the man who took on Narendra Modi |date=22 April 2011 |newspaper=IBN Live }}</ref> During this period, the [[Godhra train burning]] and the subsequent [[2002 Gujarat riots|Hindu-Muslim riots]] led to over a thousand deaths in February-March 2002.
On 9 September 2002, Narendra Modi allegedly mocked the high [[Muslim population growth|Muslim birth rates]] during a speech at [[Bahucharaji]]. Though Modi denied making such remarks, the [[National Commission for Minorities]] (NCM) sought a report from the State Government.<ref name="rediff_2002_speech"/> Modi's Principal Secretary P K Mishra told ''The Indian Express'' that the State Government had no recordings or transcripts of the speech, and therefore, could not send these to the NCM.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/should-we-run-relief-camps-open-child-producing-centres/217398 |title='Should We Run Relief Camps? Open Child Producing Centres?' |date=30 September 2002 |publisher=Outlook }}</ref> However, the State Intelligence Bureau provided the NCM a copy of Modi's speech, which had been recorded as part of routine procedure. Subsequently, the Modi government transferred the Bureau's senior officials on 'punishment postings'. The officers transferred included Sanjiv Bhatt, [[R. B. Sreekumar]] and E. Radhakrishnan. Bhatt was posted as principal of the State Reserve Police Training College.<ref name="rediff_2002_speech">{{cite news |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2002/sep/18guj2.htm |title=Gujarat IB officers transferred for putting Modi's controversial speech on record |publisher=rediff.com |date=18 September 2002 }}</ref>
=== Sabarmati Jail ===
In 2003, Bhatt was posted as the superintendent of Sabarmati central jail. There, he became very popular among the prisoners. He introduced desserts like [[gajar ka halwa]] on the jail menu. He also posted undertrials in [[Godhra train burning]] case on a jail committee. Two months after his appointment, he was transferred for being too friendly with the prisoners and bestowing favours upon them. On 18 November 2003, nearly half of the 4000 prisoners went on a hunger strike to protest his transfer. Six convicts slashed their wrists in protest.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011">{{cite news |url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/the-man-who-took-on-modi/857456/0 |title=The Man who took on Modi |date=9 October 2011 |newspaper=Indian Express |author=Leena Misra }}</ref>
By 2007, Bhatt's colleagues from the 1988 batch had been promoted to the rank of [[Inspector-general of police]] (IGP). However, Bhatt had stayed at the SP level for a decade without any promotion, because of the pending criminal cases and departmental inquiries against him.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/>
== Allegations against Gujarat Government ==
=== Affidavit against Narendra Modi ===
After the 2002 riots, a group of social activists had formed the ''Concerned Citizens Tribunal'' to analyze the riots. Gujarat's home minister [[Haren Pandya]] allegedly told this tribunal that Modi had organised a meeting at the Chief Minister's residence on 27 February 2002, after the [[Godhra train burning]], in which over 50 Hindu pilgrims died. According to Pandya, in this meeting, Modi had asked the police officials not to come in the way of "the Hindu backlash". Pandya had named a number of police officials who attended this meeting; Bhatt was not among these. Pandya was later assassinated by unidentified men.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=WxeLBgAAQBAJ&lpg=PT192&pg=PT192 |title=Gujarat Riots: The True Story |publisher=Partridge |year=2002 |author=M D Deshpande |isbn=9781482841633 |page=192 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/a-plot-from-the-devils-lair/215889 |title=A Plot From The Devil's Lair |author=Manu Joseph and S Anand |publisher=Outlook |date=3 June 2002 }}</ref>
On 14 April 2011, 9 years after the riots, Bhatt filed an affidavit in the [[Supreme Court of India]], making similar allegations. According to Bhatt, at this meeting on 27 February 2002, Modi asked top police officials to let Hindus "vent out their anger" against the Muslims.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/sanjiv-bhatt-dismissed-from-ips/article7558253.ece |title=Gujarat IPS officer who took on Modi after 2002 riots sacked |author=Mahesh Langa |newspaper=The Hindu |date=19 August 2015 }}</ref> He said that the meeting determined to bring the bodies of the Hindu pilgrims to [[Ahmedabad]] prior to cremation, and that he had cautioned against this, fearing religious violence.<ref name=HT20120104>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Ahmedabad/Sanjiv-Bhatt-seeks-access-to-state-IB-records-again/Article1-791275.aspx |title=Sanjiv Bhatt seeks access to state IB records again |publisher=Hindustan Times |location=Ahmedabad |date=4 January 2012 |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref> According to him, Modi's [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) and the [[Hindutva|Hindu nationalist]] [[Bajarang Dal]] were stirring tensions in the city, and the [[Vishwa Hindu Parishad]] (VHP) had proposed a [[bandh]] (an illegal general strike). Bhatt claimed that the then [[Director General of Police]], K. Chakravarthi, and the city Police Commissioner, [[P. C. Pandey]], had raised concerns regarding the manpower available to deal with this, and both men advised that it was not wise for the bodies to be taken to Ahmedabad.<ref name="IT_sticks_2011" /> Bhatt also says that he sent some fax messages to major officials soon after the meeting ended and that these referred to the meeting itself, the decision regarding the bodies of the dead and the growing activity of the BJP and Bajrang Dal.<ref name=Hindu20120116 /> Subsequently, riots occurred in which around 1000 people died,<ref name=HT20120104 /> three-quarters of whom were Muslim.<ref name=BBC20071223>{{cite news |publisher=BBC |location=London |title=Gujarat riot death toll revealed |date=11 May 2005 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4536199.stm |accessdate=6 July 2015}}</ref> Described as a [[whistleblower]] both by some of the Indian media and some [[pressure group]]s, Bhatt has since referred to the events as "state-sponsored riots"<ref name=ET20111018>{{cite news |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-10-18/news/30295906_1_sanjiv-bhatt-sabarmati-jail-ips-officer|title=IPS officer Sanjiv Bhatt granted bail|publisher=The Economic Times |location=Ahmedabad |date=18 October 2011|accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref> and has alleged both that Modi told his officials to be "indifferent" towards rioters and said that Muslims needed to be "taught a lesson".<ref name="IT_sticks_2011">{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/godhra-sanjiv-bhatt-sticks-to-charges-against-narendra-modi-before-nanavati-panel/1/138369.html|title=Bhatt sticks to charges against Modi before Nanavati panel|publisher=India Today |location=Ahmedabad |date=16 May 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref>
In his affidavit, Bhatt mentioned six witnesses, who could testify his presence in the alleged meeting held at Modi's residence. He claimed that he had traveled to Modi's residence in the official car of K. Chakravarthi, which was being driven by Tarachand Yadav; Bhatt's own driver Constable KD Panth followed them in Bhatt's official car. Bhatt's affidavit was signed by KD Panth, whose statement supported Bhatt's presence at the alleged meeting. On 24 June 2011, Panth filed an [[First Information Report|FIR]] against Bhatt, alleging that Bhatt had threatened him and forced him to sign a false affidavit.<ref name="TH_Manas_2011">{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/modi-government-arrests-sanjiv-bhatt/article2500664.ece |title=Modi government arrests Sanjiv Bhatt |date=23 October 2011 |newspaper=The Hindu |author=Manas Dasgupta }}</ref> Panth alleged that Bhatt took him to residence of [[Arjun Modhwadia]], the state president of the opposition party, [[Indian National Congress]]. He further alleged that Modhwadia asked him to obey Bhatt.<ref name="FP_bail_2011">{{cite web |url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/arrested-guj-cop-sanjeev-bhatt-granted-bail-109270.html |title=Arrested Guj-cop Sanjeev Bhatt granted bail |date=17 October 2011 |publisher=Firstpost }}</ref> Panth claimed that he was on leave in February 2002, when the riots broke out, and had already told this to the Supreme Court-appointed Special Investigation Team (SIT).<ref name="TH_Manas_2011"/> Chakravarthi also denied that Bhatt was present in the meeting.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/>
However, Tarachand Yadav supported Bhatt, stating that he had driven Bhatt to Modi's bungalow, and that Panth had been with them. He also supported Bhatt's claim that he travelled there with Chakrabarthy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/truth-lies-between-bhatt-s-exdriver-exboss/780573/0 |title=Truth lies between Bhatt’s ex-driver, ex-boss |date=24 April 2011 |newspaper=Indian Express }}</ref>
When questioned why he had not made these revelations earlier, Bhatt stated that in 2004, he "started sending out feelers" that he wanted to be cross-examined by the Nanavati Commission, but the Commission had not called him.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/> In May 2011, Bhatt repeated the allegations made in his affidavit when he was called to give evidence to the NMC.<ref name="IT_sticks_2011"/> Prior to this appearance and in order to support the statements that he would make during it, Bhatt had attempted to obtain documents as evidence from the police and the [[State Intelligence Bureau]], as well as from the SIT hearing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/modiaccuser-cop-says-hes-being-denied-records/151852-3.html|title= Cop says he is being denied records.|publisher=IBN |location=Ahmedabad |first=Meghdoot |last=Sharon |date=10 May 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> He again requested this information in December 2011, claiming that it was needed in order that it could be placed on the official record. These requests for information failed, and Bhatt alleged that this was because the Modi government opposed them because it was involved in a "cover up".<ref name=HT20120104 /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/modi-is-dramatis-personae-of-gujarat-carnage-2002-sanjiv-bhatt/891345/ |title=Modi is 'dramatis personae' of Gujarat 'carnage' 2002: Sanjiv Bhatt|publisher=Indian Express |date=23 December 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> In 2012, he alleged that the NMC had consistently refused to demand production of the documents, despite Bhatt's belief that it has the legal powers to do so.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article2775308.ece |title=Nanavati panel can call for any document, insists Bhatt |publisher=The Hindu |date=5 January 2012 |accessdate=9 June 2012 |location=Chennai}}</ref>
Bhatt's ex-boss [[R. B. Sreekumar]] stated that Bhatt had never told him about his presence at the meeting during these nine years. But he told the [[Nanavati-Mehta commission|Nanavati Commission]] that in 2002, the Modi government had asked the State Intelligence Bureau to tap Haren Pandya's phone to confirm that he was the minister who talked to the ''Concerned Citizens Tribunal''. <ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/>
=== Allegations against SIT ruled baseless ===
In March 2008, the Supreme Court had appointed a Special Investigation Team (SIT), headed by former [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] chief [[R. K. Raghavan]], to investigate cases relating to the various incidents that had occurred during the 2002 riots. One of those who died in the [[Gulbarg Society massacre]] that formed a part of the riots was [[Ehsan Jaffri]], the former [[Indian National Congress]] [[Member of Parliament]]. His widow, Zakia Jaffri, subsequently became concerned about the involvement of senior officials in allegedly aiding and abetting the rioters and by the lack of legal action against them by the police. She petitioned the Court, alleging criminal conspiracy, a "deliberate and intentional failure" to protect life and property, and failure to fulfil their constitutional duty. In 2009, the Court responded by directing the SIT to investigate the actions of Modi and 62 other people, including Pandey and some VHP leaders.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=The Economic Times |location=New Delhi |title=Scan Modi: SC to SIT |date=28 April 2009 |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2009-04-28/news/28480956_1_post-godhra-gulbarga-society-riots |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref> Bhatt presented evidence to this particular SIT investigation in 2009.<ref name=Statesman20110505>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&show=archive&id=368433&catid=36&year=2011&month=05&day=6&Itemid=66|title=SC for independent overview of SIT report |publisher=The Statesman |location=New Delhi |date=5 May 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref>
In his 2011 affidavit, Bhatt accused the SIT of trying to "hide the truth behind the riots".<ref name="IT_implicates_2011">{{cite news |publisher=India Today |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/2002-gujarat-riots-ips-officer-implicates-narendra-modi/1/136004.html |title=IPS officer implicates Narendra Modi in 2002 Gujarat riots |location=New Delhi |date=22 April 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> Bhatt alleged that a mole in SIT leaked information to the Modi Government, through Gujarat's additional advocate general Tushar Mehta. Mehta and Bhatt were good friends since the 1980s, until 2010. Bhatt claimed that he happened to access Mehta's account to book two vacations for their families: one to Goa in September 2009 and another to the US in May-June 2010. At that time, he claims, he saw emails from SIT in Mehta's inbox. Mehta alleged that their friendship ended because of something that happened during their 2010 vacation in the US; he refused to go into details calling it a personal affair. In August 2011, Mehta lodged a complaint against Bhatt, accusing him of hacking into his email account. Bhatt's wife Shweta denied the accusation, stating that her husband only helped Mehta because the latter was not good with computers.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/>
The Court had previously appointed [[Raju Ramachandran]] to act as ''[[amicus curiae]]'' (friend of the court). Ramachandran had reviewed the original confidential SIT report that had been submitted in November 2010. His report was also confidential but prompted the Court to order the SIT to conduct a self-review. That self-review had been submitted in April 2011<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-06/india/29516329_1_amicus-jakia-jafri-sanjiv-bhatt|title=SIT rejects Gujarat cop Bhatt's riot charges against Modi|publisher=The Times of India |location=New Delhi |first=Dhananjay |last=Mahapatra |date=6 May 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> and the Court referred this for consideration by Ramachandran in May, which was also when it refused to accept Bhatt's affidavit.<ref name=IT20110506>{{cite news |title=Relief for Narendra Modi as SC doesn't take on record IPS officer Sanjiv Bhatt's affidavit |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/the-supreme-court-has-rejected-sanjiv-bhatts-affidavit/1/137268.html |publisher=India Today |date=6 May 2011 |first=D. P. |last=Bhattacharya |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref>
In June 2011, Bhatt filed a [[Public-interest litigation (India)|Public-interest litigation]] (PIL) in the Supreme Court, calling for an independent agency to investigate the riots or, alternatively, for the case to be transferred outside Gujarat.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/gujarat/sc-notice-to-centre-gujarat-govt-on-bhatt-s-pil_722852.html |title=SC notice to Centre, Gujarat govt on Bhatt’s PIL |publisher=Zee News |date=29 June 2011 |accessdate=20 January 2012}}</ref> Bhatt also alleged that his emails had been hacked and filed a complaint against the state alleging that they had been leaked from the SIT.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/bhatt-vs-gujarat-govt-hacked-email-vs-email/827972/2 |title=Bhatt vs Gujarat govt: Hacked email vs email |publisher=Indian Express |date=6 August 2011 |accessdate=20 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/gujarat-riots-cases-compromised-allegations-of-leaks-via-emails-124613 |title=Gujarat riot cases compromised|publisher=NDTV |date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=18 January 2012}}</ref>
On 13 October 2015, a bench comprising Supreme Court Chief Justice H L Dattu and Justice Arun Mishra ruled Bhatt's allegations against the SIT as totally "false and baseless".<ref name=":4" /> It further rebuked Bhatt, ruling that "He had exchanged e-mails with rival political party leaders and was being tutored by the lawyer of an NGO and its activist... The petitioner has even sent e-mails to influence the judicial proceedings of a 3-Judge Bench of this court and has tried to influence the amicus curiae."<ref name=":3" />
=== Suspension ===
On 8 August 2011, the Gujarat government suspended Bhatt, accusing him of unauthorised absence from duty, not appearing before an inquiry committee and using his official car while not on duty.<ref name="ToI_2011_arrested">{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Gujarat-IPS-officer-Sanjeev-Bhatt-who-took-on-Narendra-Modi-arrested/articleshow/10191519.cms |title=Gujarat IPS officer Sanjeev Bhatt who took on Narendra Modi arrested |date=1 October 2011 |newspaper=The Times of India }}</ref>
Bhatt claimed that he was unable to report for work because he was required to attend various legal and investigatory hearings, including those of [[Nanavati-Mehta commission|Nanavati-Mehta Commission]] (NMC) — originally known as the Nanavati-Shah Commission — which had been established by the government of Gujarat.<ref name="TH_Manas_2011"/>
== Allegations in Haren Pandya murder case ==
The Gujarat government had originally appealed the court to drop charges against Bhatt and other policemen in the 1990 custodial death case. However, after Bhatt's affidavit against Modi, the Government withdrew its application, and the court initiated criminal proceedings against the policemen.<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/> On 18 September, the Gujarat Home Ministry chargesheeted Bhatt in the 1990 police atrocity case.<ref name="ToI_2011_arrested"/> On 27 September 2011, Bhatt appeared before the Gujarat High Court in the police atrocity case against him in [[Jamnagar district]]. During the hearing, he told the Court that Narendra Modi and his former Home Minister [[Amit Shah]] had pressurised him to destroy crucial evidence in the [[Haren Pandya]] murder case.<ref name="Outlook_2011_arrested">{{cite news |url=http://www.outlookindia.com/news/article/whistleblower-gujarat-cop-sanjiv-bhatt-arrested/736777 |title='Whistleblower' Gujarat Cop Sanjiv Bhatt Arrested |date=30 September 2011 |publisher=Outlook }}</ref>
In a fresh affidavit, Bhatt made detailed allegations against Modi and Shah. He claimed that while posted as Superintendent of the Sabarmati Jail in 2003, he had met Asgar Ali, an accused in the Haren Pandya murder case. Ali allegedly told him that Pandya had been killed by [[Tulsiram Prajapati]] (who was later killed in a [[fake encounter]] in 2006).<ref name="IE_Leena_2011"/> Bhatt claimed that he had immediately informed Home Minister Amit Shah about this revelation, but Shah asked him to destroy all documentary evidence related to this matter. He claimed that he had been removed as the Jail Superintendent because he had refused to obey Shah.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/i-was-pressured-to-withdraw-my-report-on-haren-pandyas-murder/article2491315.ece |title=‘I was pressured to withdraw my report on Haren Pandya's murder' |date=28 September 2011 |author=Manas Dasgupta |newspaper=The Hindu }}</ref>
== Arrest ==
On 30 September 2011, Bhatt was arrested, following an investigation into KD Panth's FIR. Bhatt alleged that Panth was following "diktats" from the Modi government, an allegation denied by Panth.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/195685/not-facing-pressure-file-complaint.html |title=Not facing pressure to file complaint against Sanjeev Bhatt, says KD Panth |date=4 October 2011 |newspaper=Deccan Herald }}</ref> Bhatt's arrest was condemned by the Congress leaders and human rights activists, who accused the Modi government of persecuting Bhatt.<ref name="TH_Manas_2011"/> The arrest gave rise to protests at places such as Ahmedabad, [[Delhi]] and [[Bangalore]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_protest-marches-in-gujarat-cities-as-support-for-sanjiv-bhatt-swells_1594896|title=Protest marches in Gujarat cities as support for Sanjiv Bhatt swells|publisher=DNA India|date=4 October 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref> The Gujarat IPS Officers Association also expressed their support for Bhatt and his family, although this was far from being unanimous and was downplayed by various senior officers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ips-officers-in-gujarat-pledge-support-to-sanjiv-bhatt/1/154358.html|title= IPS officers in Gujarat pledge support to Sanjiv Bhatt|publisher=India Today|date=10 September 2011|accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref> Bhatt has referred to being harassed by members of the Gujarat police.<ref name=IE20111017>{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/sanjiv-bhatt-calls-modi-a-common-criminal/861179/|title=Sanjiv Bhatt calls Modi a 'common criminal'|publisher=Indian Express |date=17 October 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref>
On 17 October 2011, Bhatt was granted [[bail]] by a local court in Ahmedabad, on condition that he continue to cooperate with investigations into the allegations laid against him. His bail application had been opposed by the Modi government.<ref name=ET20111018 /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/gujarat-suspended-ips-officer-sanjiv-bhatt-gets-bail/860916/0 |title=Gujarat: Suspended IPS officer Sanjiv Bhatt gets bail |publisher=Indian Express |location=Ahmedabad |date=17 October 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref> The Supreme Court suspended the case in April 2012, with Bhatt arguing that the arrest was "politically motivated".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-17781286|title=India court stays trial of Gujarat riots policeman |publisher=BBC |date=20 April 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref>
Bhatt was among those who refused to accept an award offered by the [[Maulana Muhammad Ali Jauhar Academy]] in 2011. This was because one of the co-awardees, [[Jagdish Tytler]], is alleged to have been involved in the [[1984 anti-Sikh riots]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_sanjiv-bhatt-refuses-to-receive-award-with-tainted-jagdish-tytler_1621893|title=Bhatt refuses to receive award with tainted Jagish Tytler |publisher=DNA |location=New Delhi |first=Iftikhar |last=Gilani |date=6 December 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
In November 2012, Bhatt and six other policemen were charged with murder in the 1990 custodial death case of Prabhudas Vaishnani.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/IPS-Sanjiv-Bhatt-charged-with-murder/articleshow/17150821.cms |title=IPS Sanjiv Bhatt charged with murder |date=9 November 2012 |newspaper=The Times of India }}</ref>
== Supreme Court ==
A former BBC journalist, Shubhranshu Choudhary, filed an affidavit in November 2011 that supported the claim that Bhatt was present at the 2002 meeting.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesnow.tv/New-affidavit-supports-Bhatts-claim/articleshow/4388865.cms |title=New affidavit supports Bhatt's claim |publisher=The Times of India |date=13 November 2011 |accessdate=18 January 2012}}</ref> In the same month, he requested that the SIT allow his testimony to be recorded in the presence of a magistrate as he believed that his earlier statements to it had been distorted.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/sanjiv-bhatt-fires-a-stinker-to-sit-chief/886472/0 |title=Sanjiv Bhatt fires a stinker to SIT chief |publisher=Indian Express |date=11 December 2011 |accessdate=18 January 2012}}</ref> He made several similar requests thereafter.<ref name=Hindu20120131 />
In January 2012, the SIT demanded the original copy of the fax messages that Bhatt claimed to have sent after the 2002 meeting and which, according to Bhatt, substantiated his presence at the meeting. Bhatt said that he had already provided the evidence in 2009 and again in 2011. He also noted that the SIT could get the information from the SIB records, and he claimed that the SIT was failing to interview police officials who could testify to his movements on the night in question.<ref name=Hindu20120116>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2804179.ece |title=SIT asks Bhatt to produce original of crucial February 27, 2002 fax message |publisher=The Hindu |date=16 January 2012 |accessdate=12 June 2012 |location=New Delhi |first=Vidya |last=Subrahmaniam}}</ref> This was not the first occasion that he had alleged the SIT was reluctant to examine key witnesses who could verify his whereabouts at the time of the meeting.<ref name=DNA20120106>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_sit-reluctant-to-examine-key-witnesses-in-riot-cases-sanjiv-bhatt_1634319 |title=SIT reluctant to examine key-witnesses in riot cases: Sanjiv Bhatt |publisher=DNA India |location=Ahmedabad |agency=PTI |date=6 January 2012 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
Bhatt has produced evidence of police inaction to SIT chairman along with a letter which had details of deployment of police, SRP and RAF in the state, areas under curfew, types of crimes committed during the riots, etc. In that letter he also alleged delayed deployment of army. He insisted that those documents were intended for the sole purpose of ensuring that crucial evidence is not disregarded or concealed by the SIT with a view to screen powerful and influential offenders from legal punishment".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/gujarat-riots-sanjiv-bhatt-submits-proof-of-police-inaction/904986/|title=Gujarat riots: Sanjiv Bhatt submits 'proof' of police inaction|publisher=Indian Express |date=28 October 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> Bhatt in a letter written to SIT alleged that the probe team didn’t exhume the bodies from well of Naroday Patia despite strong evidences catered by him to support his claim. He also complained that Ahmedabad police commissioner P. C. Pandey was alerted on the same.<ref name=Hindu20120131>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/article2845551.ece|title=Sanjiv Bhatt again rakes up bodies dumping issue |publisher=The Hindu |date=31 January 2012 |accessdate=31 January 2012 |location=Chennai |first=Manas |last=Dasgupta}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/SIT-did-not-exhume-bodies-from-Naroda-Patia-well-Bhatt/articleshow/11692863.cms |title=SIT did not exhume bodies from Naroda Patia well: Bhatt |publisher=The Times of India |date=31 January 2012|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
In February 2012, Bhatt accused the SIT of destroying evidence in collusion with the Gujarat government.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2883098.ece |title=Modi Govt, SIT destroyed evidence says Bhatt |publisher=The Hindu |location=Ahmedabad |date=11 February 2012 |first=Manas |last=Dasgupta |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> Bhatt has once again written to the NMC seeking state intelligence and police records, documents and log books pertaining to Godhra riots as he thought the remaining records too may be destroyed by the Government.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2883098.ece|title=Decision Godhra riots: Bhatt writes to probe panel again, seeks records|publisher=The Hindu |date=12 February 2012 |accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
He also claimed before the panel that Modi was wantonly giving misleading answers and unfortunately the investigation officer didn’t contradict him with all evidences that were available at his disposal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article2929259.ece |title=Modi knew what was happening in Gulberg Society: Bhatt|publisher=The Hindu |date=25 February 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2012}}</ref>
Bhatt suggested in March 2012 that the final report of the NMC should be submitted to the governor of Gujarat rather than to its chief minister, Modi. He also thought that the earlier NMC report, which concerned the Godhra train incident and had been produced in 2008, should be recalled from the chief minister and presented instead to the governor. The basis for his request was that Modi's actions formed a part of the terms of reference of the enquiry and that ""no person shall be a judge in his own cause".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_nanavati-report-should-be-submiited-to-guj-governor-sanjiv-bhatt_1660782 |title=Nanavati report should be submiited to Guj Governor: Sanjiv Bhatt'|publisher=DNA India |location=Ahmedabad |agency=PTI |date=10 March 2012 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> He also criticised the earlier report, in which the NMC had exonerated Modi of any wrongdoing in relation to the riots. Bhatt believed that the NMC lacked the official authority to make such a statement. He also criticised the failure of the NMC to summon Modi to appear before it,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_sanjiv-bhatt-questions-nanavati-commission-on-narendra-modi_1669498 |title=Sanjeev Bhatt questions Nanavati Commission on Modi |publisher=DNA |location=Ahmedabad |agency=PTI |date=30 March 2012 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref> and a few days later he requested that Modi should be summoned on the basis of an affidavit that had been filed with the Commission by the late [[Amarsinh Chaudhary]], a former Gujarat Chief Minister, in 2002. Bhatt claimed that the affidavit showed that Chaudhary had met with Modi during the period of the riots because he was concerned about reports of events in the Gulbarg Society, including the situation of Ehsan Zafri. According to Bhatt, the affidavit records that Chaudhary had found Modi to be not very "responsive" when they met and that he had received reports that the police were not acting as they should during the events.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article3282421.ece |title=Deliberate inaction on Modi's part during riots: Sanjiv Bhatt |first=Manas |last=Dasgupta |publisher=The Hindu |location= |date=5 April 2012 |accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref>
=== Supreme Court Ruling === Bhatt had filed a plea before the Supreme Court seeking a special investigative probe into two First Information Reports filed against him by the Gujarat Police.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.legalera.in/news-deals/supreme-court/judgments/item/17682-sc-dismisses-ex-ips-officer-s-plea.html|title = Supreme Court dismisses plea of former IPS Officer|date = 13 October 2015|accessdate = 13 October 2015|website = legalera.in|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The first FIR was for forcing his official driver, K D Panth, a subordinate officer, to file a false affidavit that he had transported Bhatt on 27 February 2002 to Chief Minister Narendra Modi's residence where Bhatt alleged that Modi had instructed officers to allow riots following the Godhra train carnage.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = Sacked IPS Sanjiv Bhatt didn't come with 'clean hands': SC - The Economic Times|url = http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/sacked-ips-sanjiv-bhatt-didnt-come-with-clean-hands-sc/articleshow/49341857.cms|website = The Economic Times|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref> The second FIR was that he had hacked the email of a law enforcement official, namely Tushar Mehta, then additional advocate general of Gujarat.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Supreme Court Dismisses Sanjiv Bhatt's Plea for SIT Probe|url = http://www.indiawest.com/news/india/supreme-court-dismisses-sanjiv-bhatt-s-plea-for-sit-probe/article_0d393032-718b-11e5-9463-bf5381b14b74.html|website = India West|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref> In his plea before the court, Bhatt asserted that both FIRs filed against him were politically motivated and should be probed by a Supreme Court monitored investigative team to uncover abuse of power by the Modi government.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Ex-Gujarat cop gets SC stick for ‘tutored’ riots remarks|url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/sc-dismisses-sanjiv-bhatt-s-2002-riots-plea-against-amit-shah/story-aQ5GnO7z2fxVN7iC4yugSN.html|website = [[Hindustan Times]]|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref>
On 13 October 2015, a bench comprising Chief Justice H L Dattu and Justice Arun Mishra dismissed Bhatt's plea and ordered a speedy trial to be conducted in both cases.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Supreme Court dismisses plea of former IPS officer|url = http://www.legalera.in/news-deals/supreme-court/judgments/item/17682-sc-dismisses-ex-ips-officer-s-plea.html|website = www.legalera.in|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref> It used email evidence to rule that Bhatt had deliberately colluded with leaders of the opposition Congress Party, NGO activists and certain elements in the media to furnish false evidence about his attendance at the 27 February 2002 meeting chaired by Modi so that he could falsely allege that Modi had incited riots.<ref name=":2" />"The exchange of emails which are self-explanatory indicate that the petitioner was in active touch with leaders of rival political party, NGOs, their lawyers, tried to play media card, and was being tutored by NGOs. The manner in which he acted is apparent from the aforesaid emails and need not be repeated. Petitioner had probably forgotten that he was senior IPS officer," the bench said. Referring to his past conduct, the bench said there were three departmental inquiries pending against him and he was also accused of committing atrocities on peaceful and innocent villagers in Jamjodhpur which resulted in the death of one person. The court said Bhatt had also invoked the provisions of TADA during his tenure. Moreover, the Court condemned Bhatt's conduct as underhanded and unbefitting of a senior police officer. <ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Sacked Gujarat Officer Sanjiv Bhatt Didn't Come With Clean Hands: Supreme Court|url = http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/supreme-court-rejects-plea-of-sacked-ips-officer-sanjiv-bhatt-for-sit-probe-1231531|website = NDTV.com|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref>
The Supreme Court on 14th Oct. 2015 cleared the way for criminal prosecution of sacked IPS officer Sanjiv Bhatt for allegedly hacking the email account of the then additional advocate general of Gujarat Tushar Mehta and for forcing a junior police official to file a false affidavit in a Gujarat riots case.<ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/SC-allows-proceedings-against-Sanjiv-Bhatt-refuses-SIT-probe/articleshow/49344981.cms</ref>
== Other ==
Bhatt’s allegation on inaction of police officers upon instruction from Modi was also supported by K. S. Subramanian who was a member of fact finding team led by former Supreme Court Justice V. R. Krishna Iyer. His conclusion was the outcome of his interaction with former Gujarat police chief Chakravarthy and P.C. Pandey who was then Ahmedabad police commissioner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Ex-top-cop-backs-Bhatt-s-charges-against-Narendra-Modi/Article1-812134.aspx|title=Ex-top cop backs Bhatt's charges against Narendra Modi|publisher = [[Hindustan Times]]|date= 16 February 2012|accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref>
At a convention marking the tenth anniversary of the Godhra, Bhatt said that he is unable to see any justice for the victims of riots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2961104.ece|title=Ten years on, no justice for Gujarat carnage victims, says Sanjiv Bhatt|publisher= www.thehindu.com|date= 5 March 2012|accessdate=7 March 2012}}</ref> Bhatt was issued summon by [[National Commission for Minorities]] along with other retired and serving police officers of Gujarat to testify the role of Modi to bring out the truth of 27 February 2002 meeting which held at Modi’s home. The summon was issued to Bhatt on the basis of a complaint filed by Niyazbibi Malek,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article2979127.ece|title=Minorities panel asks Bhatt, 6 others to testify on Modi meeting|publisher= www.thehindu.com|date= 10 March 2012|accessdate=11 March 2012}}</ref>
Bhatt contacted [[Pratibha Patil]], the Indian President, in April 2012. He sought a probe against Modi. He has requested the centre to appoint two member commission to enquire the role and conduct of Modi, his officials and police officers in the Godhra massacre. He also demanded an investigation into the government’s measures on the rehabilitation for victims.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article3364586.ece |title=2002 riots: Bhatt appeals to President to appoint new probe panel |publisher=The Hindu |date=28 April 2012 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref>
The SIT released all details of its investigations related to the Jaffri complaint of complicity on 7 May 2012, following deposition of its final report with the courts. The release included the two reports of Ramachandran, the ''amicus'', that had been submitted in January and July 2011. The documents revealed that the SIT believed that Bhatt had not been present at the meeting and that this was supported both by statements from those who had been present and by analysis of Bhatt's telephone records, which suggested that he was in Ahmedabad at the time.<ref name=Hindu20120507>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3393808.ece |title=Proceed against Modi for Gujarat riots: amicus |publisher=The Hindu |location=Ahmedabad/New Delhi |date=7 May 2012 |accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref> The SIT also found that the fax message that Bhatt claimed to have sent never existed and he concocted it later and the signatures of his superior officers were forged.<ref name=Hindu20120510>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3401728.ece |title=SIT rejects amicus curiae's observations against Modi |publisher=The Hindu |location=Ahmedabad |date=10 May 2012 |accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> Their preliminary report did note that there was a lack of credibility among the witnesses present at the meeting, some of whom had retired and were claiming either a loss of memory or had been in receipt of retirement benefits that might impact upon their neutrality. In addition, the SIT considered Bhatt to be an unreliable witness who had attempted to coach other witnesses, had not provided adequate explanation for his nine-year silence regarding the events surrounding the meeting and had been imprecise in his description of the events. They also though that he had "an axe to grind" against the state.<ref name=Hindu20120507/>
The Ramachandran reviews painted a different picture. He queried how the SIT could rely on the testimony of witnesses who were present at the meeting when the investigation had itself raised doubts concerning their credibility, and he provided a rationale that could explain Bhatt's presence despite his relatively low rank. He also disputed the SIT conclusions regarding the telephone records analysis and said that the matter of presence needed to be tested in court because the evidence available was insufficient to discount Bhatt's claim. Bhatt had claimed that there were two meetings on the day in question, at different times. Ramachandran's reports also showed that he thought that, if they were true, the alleged statements made by Modi were actionable in law and that the veracity of those allegations should also be tested in court. Ramachandran accepted that Bhatt had not acted in a manner consistent with his official duties but noted that {{quote|In my opinion, despite the aforesaid background, it does not appear very likely that a serving police officer would make such a serious allegation against Mr. Modi, the Chief Minister of the State, without some basis. There is no documentary material of any nature whatsoever which can establish that Shri Bhatt was not present in the meeting on 27.02.2002.<ref name=Hindu20120507 />}}
There were other differences of opinion between the SIT and Ramachandran but there were also points upon which they agreed. One of these was that the murdered [[Haren Pandya]], who had been the Gujarat Home Minister at the time of the riots but later had a falling out with Modi,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/bhatt-lawyer-links-arrest-to-pandya-case/854188/|title=Bhatt lawyer links arrest to Pandya case |publisher=Indian Express |date=1 October 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref> could not have been at the meeting and therefore could not have vouched for Bhatt's presence there, as had been claimed by a former judge in February 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/2002-gujarat-riots-former-judge-speaks-out-against-modi-says-sit-ignored-testimonies-177298|title=Former judge says there’s audio tape with evidence against Modi.|publisher= NDTV |date=17 February 2012 |accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref>
Shweta Bhatt contested unsuccessfully against Modi in the 2012 state assembly elections.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/sanjiv-bhatts-wife-to-take-on-modi/article4149896.ece |title=Modi files papers as Congress fields Shweta Bhatt against him |newspaper=The Hindu |date=30 November 2012}}</ref>
After the official release of the Amicus curiae’s report, ''[[The Times of India]]'' described Bhatt as pivot in the case against Modi.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Sanjiv-Bhatt-the-pivot-in-case-against-Modi/articleshow/13059981.cms|title= Sanjiv Bhatt the pivot in case against Modi|publisher=[[the Times of India]]|date= 9 May 2012|accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref> Bhatt criticised the published SIT report on the Godhra attack, claiming that the SIT was shielding Modi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3426438.ece|title= Your closure report a bid to shield Modi, Bhatt tells Raghavan |publisher =[[The Hindu]]|date= 17 May 2012|accessdate=17 May 2012}}</ref> Besides his deposition before NCM, Bhatt has filed an affidavit in National Commission of Minorities (NCM).In his affidavit Bhatt has asked the rights panel to initiate action against the SIT headed by R K Raghavan for incorrectly recording his statements or tweaking them to give a clean chit to Chief Minister Narendra Modi. He also alleged that certain very crucial portions of his statement, including the timings of extremely consequential meetings with the chief minister Narendra Modi on 27 February & 28 February 2002, have either been incorrectly recorded or deliberately tweaked by the SIT, possibly with the ulterior motive and intent of shielding certain powerful persons including the chief minister from legal punishment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/sit-played-with-evidence-bhatt-tells-ncm/955592/|title = SIT played with evidence,Bhatt tells NCM|publisher = [[the Indian Express]] |date= 30 May 2012|accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref>
== Personal safety ==
Concerns have been raised at various times regarding the personal safety of Bhatt. At the time of filing his Supreme Court affidavit in April 2011, Bhatt requested the Court for protection<ref name="IT_implicates_2011" /> and the Gujarat government assured the Supreme Court that it would provide personal safety arrangements.<ref name=Outlook20120214>{{cite news|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=751360|title=Bhatt Demands Adequate Security From Gujarat Govt |publisher=Outlook |date=14 February 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> This situation had arisen because Bhatt believed that the SIT had passed on his testimony to the state government and thus he feared for the security of himself and his family.<ref name=NDTV20110423>{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/bhatt-s-driver-backs-his-claim-says-he-went-to-modi-s-house-on-day-of-meet-100883|title=Gujarat police officer’s driver backs his claim|publisher=NDTV |location=New Delhi |date=23 April 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
His wife, Shweta, alleged that there was harassment during the period that he spent in jail under arrest in October 2011. She requested that the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (India)|Ministry of Home Affairs]] (MHA) of the [[Government of India]] intervene to ensure that both he and his family were protected. The MHA instructed the government of Gujarat accordingly.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/home-ministry-gujarat-ips-pfficer-sanjeev-bhatt-security/1/153665.html |title=Home ministry writes to Gujarat Govt on IPS officer Sanjeev Bhatt|publisher=India Today |date=4 October 2011|accessdate=9 June 2012}}</ref>
Bhatt had been provided with two personal guards but considered this to be insufficient. In November 2011 he requested improved security, including provision of a bullet proof car.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/bhatt-seeks-more-security-bulletproof-car/871819/0 |title=Bhatt seeks more security|publisher=Indian Express |date=7 November 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> He repeated his demands in February 2012, when he also raised objections on personal safety grounds to a request from the Gujarat police that he should return his service revolver.<ref name=Outlook20120214 />
In November 2013 Bhatt alleged that city police was not providing him adequate security, and there was an increased threat to his and his family members' lives from the "right-wing fundamentalists and the supporters of [[Narendra Modi]]". Earlier, Bhatt had alleged that his security had been downsized. The office of Commissioner of Police Shivanand Jha said that after the assessment of threat perception, it was decided that Bhatt should be provided with two armed personal security officers. However, Bhatt wrote to the commissioner, saying that he was being "provided with only one armed PSO".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/bhatt-complains-he-is-not-getting-adequate-security-113110900696_1.html |title=Bhatt complains he is not getting adequate security | publisher=Business Standard |date=9 November 2013 }}</ref>
== Removal from Service ==
Bhatt was removed from the IPS on 19 August 2015 on the ground of "unauthorised absence".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Suspended Gujarat IPS officer Sanjiv Bhatt sacked - The Times of India|url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Suspended-Gujarat-IPS-officer-Sanjiv-Bhatt-sacked/articleshow/48546732.cms|accessdate = 2015-08-19}}</ref>

'''Sarvanivāraṇaviṣkambhin''' ([[Chinese language|Chinese]]: Chú Gàizhàng Púsà 除蓋障菩薩; or Jìngzhū Yèzhàng Púsà 凈諸業障菩薩; [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan]]: སྒྲིབ་པ་རྣམ་སེལ་ ''Dribpa Namsel'') is a [[bodhisattva]] revered in [[Mahāyāna Buddhism]]. He is one of the Eight Great Bodhisattvas with [[Mañjuśrī]], [[Samantabhadra]], [[Avalokiteśvara]], [[Mahāsthāmaprāpta]], Âkāśagarbha ([[Akasagarbha]]), [[Kṣitigarbha]] and [[Maitreya]].
==Role== He is invoked to remove or eliminate all the obstacles to insure a successful meditation.
==Nivāraṇa== Although the eight Mahāsattvas belong to the current Mahāyāna, the term nivāraṇa is most commonly used in the Theravada texts where it refers to the five mental obstacles: desire (kamacchanda), hostility (vyapada), laziness (thinamiddha), distraction and worry (uddhachcha-kukuchcha), doubts (vichikicha) towards the [[Three Jewels]]. Sarvanivāraṇaviṣkambhi is best known to meditators and is not an important subject to individual worship like the other seven mahāsattvas.
==In Vajrayāna== In Tantric Buddhism, he is usually placed in the lineage of [[Amoghasiddhi]] Buddha, one of the five Dhyani Buddhas, more rarely of [[Akshobhya]] Buddha. He is sometimes considered a form of [[Vajrapāṇi]], though this is most likely a confusion with the mahāsattva Mahāsthāmāprāpta which Vajrapāṇi is one of its incarnations.
==Iconography== In iconography, he has often a flower in one hand, sometimes with a jewel (Cintamaṇi).
==Sutras concerned== He is mentioned in the [[Lotus Sutra]], in which he pays homage to Avalokiteśvara, and in the [[Mahavairocana Tantra]].
==Mantra== The mantra of this great bodhisattva to remove all obstacles and disturbances mentioned in the Vairocana-sūtra, is as follows:
'''namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ/ aḥ/ sattva hitābhyudgata/ traṃ/ traṃ/ raṃ/ raṃ/ svāhā'''
==Bibliography== Radha Banerjee: Ashtamahābodhisattva, the Eight Great Bodhisattvas in Art and Literature, Abha Prakashan, ({{ISBN|81-85704-22-8}})

[[Royal Canadian Regiment of Infantry]] |battles= [[Fenian Raids]] * [[Battle of Ridgeway]] [[North-West Rebellion]] * [[Battle of Cut Knife]] [[Second Boer War]] * [[Battle of Paardeberg]]. |awards= [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]]
[[Volunteer Officers' Decoration]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[General (Canada)|General]] '''Sir William Dillon Otter''', {{postnominals|country=CAN|size=100%|sep=,|KCB|CVO|VD}} (December 3, 1843 – May 6, 1929) was a professional Canadian soldier who became the first Canadian-born [[Commander of the Canadian Army|Chief of the General Staff]], the head of the [[Canadian Militia]]. ==Military career== Otter was born near [[The Corners, Canada West]]. His parents were Anna Louisa, née de la Hooke (1824–1907) and Alfred William Otter (1815–1866),The son of [[William Otter]], Bishop of Chichester both English immigrants who married in Ontario on 15 September 1842. He began his military career in the [[Non-Permanent Active Militia]] in [[Toronto]] in 1864. Captain William Otter was Adjutant of the [[Queen's Own Rifles of Toronto]] in 1866. He first saw combat with them at the [[Battle of Ridgeway]] during the [[Fenian Raids]]. He joined the [[Permanent Active Militia|Permanent Force]] as an [[infantry]] officer when Canada established its own professional infantry unit in 1883. On May 2, 1885, he led a Canadian force of more than 300 in the [[Battle of Cut Knife]] against [[Pitikwahanapiwiyin|Poundmaker's]] [[Cree]] Indians. Otter's tactics were ineffective against the defending warriors, forcing him to retreat. In 1890, Otter founded the [[Royal Canadian Military Institute]] as a body for "the promotion and fostering of military art, science and literature in Canada." The Gen Sir William Otter Papers are selected from those presented at events organized by the Defence Studies Committee of the Royal Canadian Military Institute.[http://www.rcmi.org/publications/otter-papers.html Gen Sir William Otter Papers] He was appointed as the first Commanding Officer of the [[Royal Canadian Regiment of Infantry]] in 1893. Lieutenant Colonel Otter commanded the Royal Canadian Regiment of Infantry at the time of the [[Second Boer War]], during which he played an important part in the Battle of Paardeburg. Otter commanded the 2nd (Special Service) Battalion of The Royal Canadian Regiment of Infantry in South Africa, where they were considered by many British officers to be the best infantry [[battalion]] in the country. He became the first Canadian-born officer to command Canada's military in 1908, and he retired in 1910 as a full general. Otter had the reputation of being something of a [[martinet]] – due mainly to his desire that the young Canadian Army should not show up badly when compared to British troops.Brian A Reid ''"Our Little Army in the Field – The Canadians in the Boer War"'' [[Image:William D Otter.JPG|thumb|250px|left|Lieutenant Colonel William Dillon Otter]] He wrote ''The Guide: A Manual for the Canadian Militia (Infantry) Embracing the Interior Economy, Duties, Discipline, Drills and Parades, Dress, Books, and Correspondence of a Battalion with Regulations for Marches, Transport & Encampment, Also Forms & Bugle Calls'' in 1914, which includes sections on discipline, courts martial, offences, complaints, and defaulters. During the First World War he came out of retirement to command operations for the [[internment]] of enemy nationals resident in Canada. Otter headed the [[Otter Commission]]. The Otter Commission was tasked to establish links of perpetuation from the units of [[Canadian Expeditionary Force]] back to the institutionally separate units of the [[Canadian Militia]] in the years following the First World War. This establishment of perpetuation, based primarily on geographical connections through original recruiting areas of the [[List of infantry battalions in the Canadian Expeditionary Force|CEF battalions]], provided a basis by which the achievements and battle honours of the CEF units transferred back to the units of the standing Militia. Without this work of the Otter Commission the CEF and its achievements would have had no continuance with existing units of the Canadian Army today. General Sir William Otter died on 6 May 1929. ==Freemason== Otter was initiated into the Ionic Lodge of Freemasonry in Toronto in February 1869. He became Worshipful Master in 1873.[http://sites.google.com/site/ionic025/notable-members/otter William Dillon Otter in Ionic Lodge] ==Legacy== [[File:William Dillon Otter sword at Royal Military College of Canada.jpg|thumb|right|220px|William Dillon Otter sword at [[Royal Military College of Canada]]]] Otter Squadron, composed of University Training Plan Non Commissioned Member Officer Cadets, at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] in [[Kingston, Ontario]], was named in his honour. ==Family connections== Otter was the grandfather of Canadian Military historian [[Desmond Morton (historian)|Desmond Morton]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * [[Desmond Morton (historian)|Desmond Morton]], The Canadian General Sir William Otter, Toronto: Hakkert, 1974. Canadian War Museum historical publication * Commander Chas. N. Robinson R.N., Celebrities of the Army, London: George Newnes Limited, 1900. * Major-General Sir William D. Otter `The Guide: A Manual for the Canadian Militia (Infantry) Embracing the Interior Economy, Duties, Discipline, Drills and Parades, Dress, Books, and Correspondence of a Battalion with Regulations for Marches, Transport & Encampment, Also Forms & Bugle Calls` Toronto: Copp, Clark & Co. 1914 ==External links== *[http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=7848 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online''] *[http://www.civilisations.ca/cwm/boer/williamotter_e.html Information from civilisations.ca] *[http://www.canadiansoldiers.com/mediawiki-1.5.5/index.php?title=Major_General_Sir_William_Dillon_Otter Information on Otter and the Otter Committee at canadiansoldiers.com] {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box|title=[[Commander of the Canadian Army|Chief of the General Staff (Canada)]]|before=[[Percy Lake|Sir Percy Lake]]| after=[[Colin John Mackenzie|Sir Colin Mackenzie]]|years=1908–1910}} {{s-end}} {{Commander of the Canadian Army}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Otter, William}} [[Category:1843 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian generals]] [[Category:Canadian Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Canadian Knights Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Canadian Commanders of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:People of the Fenian Raids]] [[Category:People of the North-West Rebellion]] [[Category:The Queen's Own Rifles of Canada]]

{{for|the British trade unionist|William Tallon (trade unionist)}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2008}} {{Infobox person | name = William Tallon, [[Royal Victorian Medal|RVM]] | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = William John Stephenson Tallon | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|11|12|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Birtley, Tyne and Wear|Birtley]], England, UK<ref name=Telegraph2007-11-26/> | death_date = {{death date and age|2007|11|23|1935|11|12|df=y}} | death_place = Kennington, London, England, UK<ref name=Telegraph2007-11-29/> | title = '''''Steward and Page of the Backstairs'''''}}
'''William John Stephenson Tallon, [[Royal Victorian Medal|RVM]]''' (12 November 1935 – 23 November 2007), also known as '''Backstairs Billy''', was a [[Steward (office)|steward]] and member of the [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Queen Mother]]'s staff at [[Clarence House]].
==Early life== Tallon grew up in Norman Place Road, [[Coundon]], Coventry and attended Barkers Butts Secondary Modern School.<ref name=CTelegraph2008-07-16/>
==Work with the Royal Family== Tallon's first job in the Royal Household was as a junior assistant, at Easter Court at [[Windsor Castle|Windsor]] in 1951, at age 13. He had been writing letters asking for work with the Household for the previous five years. He was later employed at [[Buckingham Palace]]. He was set to join [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] on her [[Commonwealth]] tour in 1953-1954 but was kept back and did his [[National Service]] with the [[Royal Air Force|RAF]]. Subsequently, he asked [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother]] if he could join the staff at her home, [[Clarence House]]. She agreed, and he remained with her until her death in 2002.<ref name=Telegraph2007-11-26 /><ref name="dailymail">{{citation|publisher=Daily Mail |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1245565/Revealed-The-secret-life-Backstairs-Billy-Queen-Mothers-loyal-servant.html|title=The secret life of Backstairs Billy, the Queen Mother's most loyal servant|date=28 January 2010|accessdate=1 May 2009}}</ref>
After the death in 2000 of his partner, Reg Wilcock,<ref name=Telegraph2007-12-07/> the ''House Deputy Steward'' and the Queen Mother's ''Page of the Presence'', Tallon reportedly suffered from depression. When the Queen Mother passed away he was heart broken.<ref name=Telegraph2007-11-26/> When she died in 2002, at age 101, Tallon left Clarence House. He settled in a ground-floor flat with a garden in [[Kennington]], where he was found dead on 23 November 2007, at age 72.<ref name=Telegraph2007-11-29/>
In 2014 Buckingham Palace reacted angrily to suggestions made in ''The Royal Life Of William Tallon'', a biography of Tallon written by Tom Quinn, that the Queen Mother "was frequently drunk and "dotty" for the final 20 years of her life." The Queen Mother's niece and former [[lady-in-waiting]], Margaret Rhodes, denied that the Queen Mother drank [[gin and tonic]], claiming that she favoured a "gin martini mix which she usually made herself".<ref>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/palace-anger-over-statements-that-queen-mother-was-insane-drunk-1481125]</ref>
==Media== *A [[Channel 4]] documentary, ''Backstairs Billy: The Queen Mum's Butler'', was broadcast in 2009.
==Awards== He was one of the few holders of the [[Royal Victorian Medal]] in Gold, being the highest award in the lowest grade of the [[Royal Victorian Order]].<ref name=Telegraph2007-11-26/> He received the Royal Victorian Medal (Gold) in June 2001, and his 50-year Service Clasp earlier that year.<ref name=Telegraph2002-08-05/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=CTelegraph2008-07-16> {{cite news | first= Barbara | last= Goulden | title = Day I had drinks below stairs at Queen Mum's | newspaper = [[Coventry Telegraph]] | date = 16 July 2008 | url = http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/coventry-news/2008/07/16/day-i-had-drinks-below-stairs-at-queen-mum-s-92746-21350439/ | accessdate = 27 January 2013}}</ref> <ref name=Telegraph2007-11-26> {{cite news | title = Obituaries - William Tallon | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 26 November 2007 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1570503/William-Tallon.html | accessdate = 27 January 2013}}</ref> <ref name=Telegraph2007-11-29> {{cite news | first= Caroline | last= Butler | title = William Tallon: 'She can make her own b***** gin and tonic...' | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 29 November 2007 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/features/3634810/William-Tallon-She-can-make-her-own-b-gin-and-tonic....html | accessdate = 27 January 2013}}</ref> <ref name=Telegraph2007-12-07> {{cite news | first= Caroline | last= Butler | title = William Tallon's funeral goes just the way he planned it | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 7 December 2007 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/features/3634920/William-Tallons-funeral-goes-just-the-way-he-planned-it.html | accessdate = 27 January 2013}}</ref> <ref name=Telegraph2002-08-05> {{cite news | first= Richard | last= Eden | title = Honours for Queen Mother's staff | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 5 August 2002 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1403582/Honours-for-Queen-Mothers-staff.html | accessdate = 27 January 2013}}</ref>}}
==External links== *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article2950280.ece Tallon obituary], ''The Times Online'' *{{cite episode|title=Last Word|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/news/lastword_30nov2007.shtml|series=Last Word|serieslink=Last Word|network=[[BBC]]|station=[[BBC Radio 4]]|airdate=30 November 2007}}

'''Xerxes Desai''' was the first managing director of [[Titan Company]], an Indian watchmaking company, and played an instrumental role in laying the foundation of the company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/WFxqxvGSp7YIsqK2LecftJ/Xerxes-Desai-The-timekeeper.html|title=Xerxes Desai: The timekeeper|last=Tandon|first=Suneera|date=2016-06-09|website=Live Mint|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>
== Biography == Desai was a graduate of [[Elphinstone College]] ([[University of Mumbai|Mumbai University]]) and [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/WFxqxvGSp7YIsqK2LecftJ/Xerxes-Desai-The-timekeeper.html|title=Xerxes Desai: The timekeeper|last=Tandon|first=Suneera|date=2016-06-09|website=Live Mint|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>
Desai joined [[Tata Administrative Services]] in 1961 after graduation, working at several of their companies. He founded Titan as a joint venture with [[J. R. D. Tata]] in 1986, with support from the [[Tamil Nadu Industrial Development Corporation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/Titans-founding-MD-Xerxes-Desai-dies-at-79/articleshow/52947577.cms|title=Titan’s founding MD Xerxes Desai dies at 79 - Times of India|website=Times of India|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref> He had suggested the idea of a watchmaking company to Tata in the 1970s, who liked it, but bureaucratic hassles took time till the company was opened in 1986 in [[Hosur]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/business/report/xerxes-desai-the-man-behind-titans-success/20160628.htm|title=Xerxes Desai: The man behind Titan's success|website=Rediff|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/fe-columnist/end-of-a-titan/300226/|title=Xerxes Desai, the Titan who changed the way Indians kept time dies|date=2016-06-29|website=The Financial Express|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZawvddLxmMwC|title=World Class In India|last=Ghoshal|first=S.|date=2002-03-04|publisher=Penguin Books Limited|isbn=9789351180272|language=en|chapter=The Indian Watch Industry: Titanic Changes}}</ref>
In 1994, Desai challenged engineers at Titan to design the world's thinnest watch, with a movement 1.15mm thick inside a 3.5mm case.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OE37CgAAQBAJ|title=Innovation Strategy for Enterprises in Emerging Economies: Case Studies for the Digital Age|last=Satpathy|first=Anurag|last2=Agrawal|first2=Arjun|last3=Mohapatra|first3=Sanjay|date=2015-11-16|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|isbn=9781785604805|pages=115–117|language=en}}</ref> The watch, called the Titan Edge was introduced in 2002.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KdVZAgAAQBAJ|title=Orbit-Shifting Innovation: The Dynamics of Ideas that Create History|last=Narang|first=Rajiv|last2=Devaiah|first2=Devika|date=2014-01-03|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|isbn=9780749468767|pages=165–166|language=en}}</ref>
After Titan's success, Desai founded [[Tanishq]], a jewelry brand. He had innovative ideas like asking people in Bangalore to get their jewelry appraised in 1999. The jewelry business grew over time, after a slow start.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/xerxes-desai-the-titan-behind-the-timekeeper-116062700808_1.html|title=Xerxes Desai: The titan behind the timekeeper|last=Krishnan|first=Raghu|website=Business Standard|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>
Desai retired in 2002, and was succeeded by his protegé Bhaskar Bhat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archives.digitaltoday.in/businesstoday/20020414/people.html|title=A Titan Departs|last=|first=|date=2002-04-14|website=|publisher=Business Today Archives|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>
=== Post retirement === Desai was awarded a Lifetime Achievement award by the [[National Institute of Design]] during its 4th Design Excellence Awards in 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiatodayimages.com/buyimage-xerxes-desai-200107-sm1-2719481.html|title=Xerxes at NID Awards, 2006|website=www.indiatodayimages.com|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>
Post retirement, Desai was a part of the Indian Institute for Human Settlements (IIHS) initiative by [[Nandan Nilekani]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/nandan-rohini-nilekani-gift-iihs-rs-50-cr/809445/|title=Nandan, Rohini Nilekani gift IIHS Rs 50 cr - Indian Express|website=archive.indianexpress.com|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>
== Death == Desai died from illness in [[Bangalore]], where he had lived for 30 years, on June 27, 2016, at the age of 79.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/YU0lGZxi8vGW383NazxsOK/Xerxes-Desai-founder-of-Titan-dies.html|title=Xerxes Desai, founder of Titan, dies|last=Skariachan|first=Dhanya|date=2016-06-27|website=Live Mint|access-date=2016-07-03}}</ref>

Major the Chevalier '''Etienne Corbisier de Meaultsart''' (19 May 1894 – 19 September 1965)<ref>''[http://www.abps.org.uk/Awards/Roll_of_Distinguished_Philatelists/RDP_Background_20111231_LR.pdf Background notes on The Roll of Distinguished Philatelists September 2011]'', Roll of Distinguished Philatelists Trust, London, 2011. [https://www.webcitation.org/6OlHSBOTl Archived here.]</ref> was a Belgian [[philatelist]] who was added to the [[Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] in 1949.
Etienne Corbisier was an expert in the philately of Belgium and Bolivia, on which countries he wrote in philatelic journals. He was the special representative of the [[Royal Philatelic Society London]] in Belgium.<ref>"Chevalier Corbisier de Meaultsart", HRH, ''[[The London Philatelist]]'', Vol. 74, 1965, p. 224.</ref>
==Selected publications== *''Canada: essai sur quelques oblitérations et marques postales.'' 1947. *''Entiers postaux - Canada - Les deux premières cartes postales.'' 1947. *''Canada''. 1951.
